Important WPForms Announcement
We are retiring the WPForms Ultimate Lifetime Plan on October 2nd.

This plan allows you to get lifetime access to all current and new WPForms features along with all updates and support.

All existing users will be grandfathered in. I just wanted to let you know in case you want to upgrade and lock in the best WPForms deal ever before it goes away.

Click Here to Upgrade » Read the Full Announcement

Thanks as always for your continuous support of WPForms!
Syed Balkhi
Founder of WPForms

item.title: Xavier's Resume
item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded: Xavier is an entrepreneur, project manager, trainer, Certified Scrum Master & Professional and Certified Microsoft professional who has spent a great deal of his career working on cutting edge projects, with a primary focus on .Net and recently iOS. His expertise is primarily web applications, search and mobile. Throughout multiple projects he has acquired skills in dealing with complex enterprise software deployments with companies that range from startups to Microsoft. Also worked as a worldwide v-trainer/evangelist for Microsoft.

item.title: About Me
item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded:
Helping .NET Developers Add Search to Their Applications.

I have to admit that there are multiple things where I am very passionate and opinionated about. However, search is one of those things were I really need to admit that I love and at the same time I get upset pretty often. Why? Because search, even though it is one of the most required functionalities in applications, it is not very well understood and more often than not it is incorrectly implemented. Therefore I have decided that I want to help a tiny bit in this development world, teaching people the beauties of search and how it should be done properly. I started with my Pluralsight training, Getting Started with Enterprise Search, followed up by an in person training, Solr for Dummies and then a Solr book that should be published soon. This blog represents this journey as I go along and help evangelize people into Solr, SolrNet and potentially other search technologies.

As Well as Entrepreneurship, Development, Authoring and more...

I am one of those people who works sometimes more than they should. There are many motivations and I have to admit that I have tried more things in terms of projects and development related than I should have. However, all good things happen for a purpose. This blog represents my growth as an individual, and all the things that I work with including Agile, Solr, .Net and more. So many good things have occurred in my life. Traveled to many new places, plus the usual ones. Have achieved several certifications which include Microsoft Professional Developer, Certified Scrum Professional and Scrum Master, Microsoft SQL Server Technology Specialist and others. Was a presenter @ Microsoft SharePoint Conference and also have several different personal projects that include iPhone dev and mobile development.  I love the idea of being able to deliver a lot of value to individuals on the go. Besides my personal projects Usados.cr and CCView.me I also provide consulting to Search Technologies and I am a Pluralsight author. I will continue telling my story here, in case you want to take a peek :) BTW: Here is my profile information if you are interested Xavier is an entrepreneur, project manager, trainer, Certified Scrum Master & Professional and Certified Microsoft professional who has spent a great deal of his career working on cutting edge projects, with a primary focus on .Net and recently iOS. His expertise is primarily web applications, search and mobile. Throughout multiple projects he has acquired skills in dealing with complex enterprise software deployments with companies that range from startups to Microsoft. Also worked as a worldwide v-trainer/evangelist for Microsoft. Enjoy!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Just a brief description of who I am

item.title: viva s blogpost structure
item.dc:creator: viva
item.content:encoded:
What is Apache Solr used for?

Solr is an open source, extremely fast and widely used search platform. Some of the world's biggest companies work with Solr. It is used for social media, for instance Linkedin uses it; science and research, Nasa works with Solr for its Nebula Cloud Computing Platform and for search engines, such as Google Search Appliance. Solr is thus behind the search and navigation features of various highly popular internet sites. 

 

So what makes Solr so widely used by companies like Apple, Netflix, Instagram, NASA, Zappos, Goldman Sachs, The White House and many more?

Well, one of the reasons is that Solr can use structured, semi-structured and unstructured data from various sources. It is able to index it and get it ready for almost perfect real - time search. But Solr has more to offer than highly performant search features. Solr also has some pretty potent analytical skills. For example, Solr can be used to get intelligent product recommendations on e-commerce websites, think of the features “Best sellers,” “Recommendations for you,” “Popular right now,” “Trending now,” and “New Releases.”

 

Solr is able to create these because it has the necessary metadata to do it. It can take care of massive amounts of transactions and an excessively high amount of updates. A company can also locate customer segments by putting customer data in Solr and querying it. Solr is able to get you a subset from a gigantic list only from a couple of criteria that you put out. 

 

So, next to having epic search features, Solr can act as an outstanding data store to use for analytical tasks. To be clear, it offers some very advanced search and analytics possibilities in any domain. Companies can effortlessly forge Solr´s flexible features to accommodate their specific needs. Solr can be used for searching DNA patterns, identifying website hackers, matching candidates to jobs or finding your soulmate! And more and more applications are created every day.

Why is Apache Solr so fast?

Solr is lightning fast because it searches for an index and doesn´t search the text directly. Consider the example of finding pages in a book by looking at the index at the back, this will save you a lot of time then when you would go through the whole book page by page. So instead of a page centric data structure there is a keyword data structure.

Can Apache Solr be used as a database?

We can use Solr with Hadoop. Considering that Hadoop tackles massive amounts of data, Solr can easily retrieve the information we need even on this level. We mentioned previously that we can also use Solr for storage purposes. Solr can act like a NoSQL database, or a non relational data storage with analytical features. Solr is therefore both a search and a storage engine that works perfectly well with vast amounts of information.

What are Apache Solr´s top features?

Let´s shine some more light on Solr´s epic features. 

Well, it can search full text, quickly find words or phrases in your data, do dimensional search, real time indexing, dynamic clustering, database integration, work with rich documents (such as word or pdf) and much much more. Solr is able to handle changes in size or scale, and it keeps operating in the event of failure with automated recovery. 

Used by oh so many and updated and developed by a whole bunch of developers and enthusiasts. 

But hold on, what does Solr actually mean? The letters stand for ¨Search on Lucene and Resin¨. Solr is built using Lucene core. Great but what is Lucene? Apache Lucene is a  Java library providing powerful indexing and search features. Because Solr is built using the Lucene core it can use all the specifics of Lucene. But with Solr you don´t need to use your existing or non existing Java skills as you do with Lucene. With Solr the applications in big data are simply endless. 

6 reasons to use Solr or 6 reasons why we like Apache Solr so much?

We would like to end this Solr expose with some of its great attributes to add clarity and make you explicitly aware of how valuable this cute little and extremely useful open source gem is.

High level Full-Text Search masteries

The search is almost real time, on different kinds of data, in various ways and with endless applicability.

Extensive User Interfaces

Solr comes with a really useful interface that will assist you with all your administrative work or search queries.

Easy to adapt to anything we want

We can use Solr for any needs we might have with our data and on any size of data we want to work on.

Massive corpus or Extensible Plugins

Again making sure we can adapt Solr to any of our needs, it comes with easy to use extension points.

Ready to wear Security

Various security hazards are taken care of such as SSL encryption, authentication and users or role authorization.

Fun oversight

Solr has many tools we can use to supervise its metrics, commercial or open source

Conclusion

We wanted to give you a light overview on Apache Solr, what is it, where is it used and why is it so valuable. Because it is open source and considered as a top priority project it is updated and developed continuously. The applications of Solr are so diverse and so pervasive and new and exciting ways to use Solr are created nearly every day. Thereby greatly improving the way we look at, work with and act upon the world in various domains.

We would like to end this Solr expose with some of its great attributes to add clarity and make you explicitly aware of how valuable this cute little and extremely useful open source gem is. <\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"1ace0f1f","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"7c05614","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"56fbe8dd","elType":"widget","settings":{"tabs":[{"tab_title":"High level Full-Text Search masteries","tab_content":"

The search is almost real time, on different kinds of data, in various ways and with endless applicability. <\/span><\/p>","_id":"c9dfb9f"},{"tab_title":"Extensive User Interfaces","tab_content":"

Solr comes with a really useful interface that will assist you with all your administrative work or search queries.<\/span><\/p>","_id":"e2b1df8"},{"_id":"1f5cdd2","tab_title":"Easy to adapt to anything we want","tab_content":"

We can use Solr for any needs we might have with our data and on any size of data we want to work on.<\/span><\/p>"},{"_id":"e141464","tab_title":"Massive corpus or Extensible Plugins","tab_content":"

Again making sure we can adapt Solr to any of our needs, it comes with easy to use extension points.<\/span><\/p>"},{"_id":"898850b","tab_title":"Ready to wear Security","tab_content":"

Various security hazards are taken care of such as SSL encryption, authentication and users or role authorization.<\/span><\/p>"},{"_id":"9190f28","tab_title":"Fun oversight","tab_content":"

Solr has many tools we can use to supervise its metrics, commercial or open source<\/span><\/p>"}]},"elements":[],"widgetType":"toggle"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"15c47168","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"22c454f7","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"197ce99b","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Conclusion"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"6cbbfda7","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"6a37a80a","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"1ad4d7af","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

We wanted to give you a light overview on Apache Solr, what is it, where is it used and why is it so valuable. Because it is open source and considered as a top priority project it is updated and developed continuously. The applications of Solr are so diverse and so pervasive and new and exciting ways to use Solr are created nearly every day. Thereby greatly improving the way we look at, work with and act upon the world in various domains.<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false}]

item.title: Road Warrior
item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded:
I've had a few opportunities in my life to travel. In here I will just try to list as many places as I can from what I can remember now. The life of the road warrior...
April 2002 - ASP.NET Connections Convention in New Orleans, US
December 2002 - SAFECO in Seattle, Seattle WA
January 2003 - Spent over a month in Mexico City, Mexico. Visited the pyramids!
June 2003 - Two conferences @ Miami & Ft Lauderdale user groups in Florida.
July 2003 - .Net Conference in San Juan, Puerto Rico
July 2003 - Skydiving in Miami, Florida
September 2003 - Baru Volcano in Panama
September 2003 - Microsoft Conference in Guadalajara
September 2003 - Microsoft Conference in Monterrey, Mexico
September 2003 - Microsoft Conference @ Horse Track in Mexico City, Mexico
December 2003 - VB.Net lab @ Building 20 in Microsoft, Redmond. Went snowboarding!
January 2004 - Consulting in Texas
February, March & April 2004 - 3 months in Microsoft, Redmond
July 2004 - MS Presentation in Boston
August 2004 - 2 weeks in Microsoft
September 2004 - MS Presentation in San Jose, California
September 2004 - Weekend @ San Francisco
October 2004 - HP Dev Forum @ Toronto, Canada. Niagara Falls too!
December 2004 - Itanium Developer Forum in New Jersey
December 2004 - Weekend@ New York with Chito!
January 2005 - One month in Microsoft, Redmond.
March 2005 - MTC in London, UK
April 2005 - MTC in Palo Alto, California
April 2005 - Building 20 @ Microsoft in Redmond

May 2005 - MTC in Toronto, Canada
May 2005 - MTC in Stockholm, Sweden
May 2005 - MTC in Seoul, Korea
May 2005 - Weekend @ Amsterdam
May 2005 - MS Presentation in Milan, Italy
May 2005 - Weekend in Venice, Italy with my great cousin Gracie!
June 2005 - MTC in Chicago
June 2005 - Vacation @ Spain. Visited: Madrid, Barcelona, Toledo, Sevilla, Granada, Cordoba & Almunnecar
June 2005 - MTC @ Embassy Golf Links Park in Bangalore, India
July 2005 - Weekend in Madrid with Pat, Karlita & Timo!
July 2005 - Itanium Developer Forum in Washington DC
August 2005 - Itanium Developer Forum in San Diego, California
August 2005 - Weekend in San Diego with Scott
September 2005 - Conference @ HP Headquarters in Mexico City, Mexico
October 2005 - Itanium Developer Forum in Houston, Texas
November 2005 - MTC in Mountain View, California
November 2005 - ISA Event in San Jose, California
December 2005, MTC in Sillicon Valley, California
December 2005, MTC in Paris, France
January 2006 - MTC in Sillicon Valley, California
February 2006 - ISA Event @ Heinz-Nixdorf-MuseumsForum in Paderborn, Germany
February 2006 - MTC @ Embassy Golf Links Park in Bangalore, India

August 2006 - Snowboarind in Chile. Party in Santiago & Vinna del Mar.
August 2006 - Seattle, WA (the rest of the month)
September 2006 - Montpellier, FR (Meditarranean Coast from Cap d’Agade to Augnes Mortes)
September 2006 - London, UK (Maria’s house!!!!)
September 2006 - Seattle, WA. Getting ready to come back to Costa Rica. Surprise!
April 2007 - Seattle, WA. Another visit to Microsoft
April 2007 - Nashville Tennesse. Went with a couple of guys from MCS to Deloitte for a Vista training.
October 2007 - Redmond, WA. More Microsoft. This time with Eric Herrera.
January 2008 - Redmond WA. Stayed at Cali’s.
April 2008 - Redmond, WA. Guess what? Microsoft! Stayed at Cali’s place.
August 2008 - Redmond, WA. More Microsoft.
January 2009 - Redmond, WA. More Microsoft. But this time with Irene! and a week vacation!
March 2009 - San Diego, CA. Consulting with Search Tech on a SharePoint project.
April 2009 - San Diego, CA. Additional work with Search Tech on the project.
April 2009 - Seattle, WA. Couple of days off. Used an $850 ticket left from my previous job to go and buy me a nice tux for the wedding.
July 2009 - Argentina on my honeymoon with my lovely wife Irene! Visited Buenos Aires, Villa La Angostura (near Bariloche) and Iguazu.
August 2009 - San Diego, CA. More SharePoint project, v1.1 sprint planning.
October 2009 - Las Vegas, NV. Presenter @ Microsoft SharePoint Conference 2009 - Search tracks
November 2009 - Alexandria, VA. Meeting at CPA - Feature discussion and review
December 2009 - Sandy beaches of the Caribbean with my wife.
March 2010 - Alexandria, VA and Washington DC working and then with Irene
April 2010 - New York City with Irene

September 2010 - Reston, VA for the kickoff
October 2010 - Denver, Colorado meetings with Mark from DealerLogix
January 2011 - Miami with Irene. On vacation & getting everything for Juliana.
March 2011 - CPA / Search Technologies sprint planning meeting in Reston and Alexandria, Virginia.
September 2011 - Virginia, US. Search Technologies Kick off
January 2012 - CPA / Search Technologies sprint planning meeting in Reston and Alexandria, Virginia.

January 2013 - London, UK. Meetings with CPA Global.

February 2014- Salt Lake City, Utah. Pluralsight's 2nd Author Summit at the Little America. And then snowmobiling in Daniel's Summit.
September 2014 - San Jose, California. Presenter at the Atlassian Summit. Collaboration is more than Communication.
September 2014 - Miami, Florida. Search Technologies Annual Kick Off, where I delivered my Solr for Dummies training.

November 2016 - Microsoft MVP Summit in Redmond

December 2016 - San Francisco
January 2017 - San Diego @ Search Technologies

Feburary 2017 - Alpharetta, GA. Solr engagement.
March 2017 - Palo Alto, Services Enablement Partner Bootcamp @ Cloudera
May 2017 - Alpharetta, GA. Solr engagement.
June 2017 - Alpharetta, GA. Solr engagement.
August 2017 - New York, Spark training @ Cloudera
September 2017 - Salt Lake City, Pluralsight Author Summit and Pluralsight Live
September 2017 - Westin Conchal - Training for Accenture / Search Technologies
September 2017 - New York, Strata Hadoop
October 2017 - Dublin, Spark Summit EU
 
I will continue to add more dates and places as I remember…

item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded:
1) Type regedit in your start menu search bar and open up the Registry Editor.
2) Navigate to:
HKEY_CURRENT_USER\CONTROL PANEL\DESKTOP
3) In the right pane, right click on ForeGroundFlashCount
4) Click on Modify, and select Decimal.
5) Change the Value to a higher number to however many flashes you want. Setting a Value of 1 will give you a single flash. Setting a Value of 0 will give you indefinite flashes. 6) Close Regedit
7) Log off and Log on or Restart the Computer to apply the changes.

item.title: Resume
item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded: XAVIER MORERA (Click here to download in a nicer format) PROGRAM MANAGER, SCRUM MASTER, MENTOR - Project Manager & Development Manager - Certified Microsoft Technology Specialist - Developer & Technical Writer - Certified Scrum Master by The Scrum Alliance - Technology Consultant & Presales Engineer - Research & Development - SEO Specialist - Presenter & Lead Trainer MAJOR ACCOMPLISHMENTS Project & Development Manager: Managed a geographically distributed development team with three different emphasis: web, FAST ESP, & database development on a multi-million dollar patent research application. Program Manager for Microsoft Corporation: Worked as a Program Manager, developer and tester for Microsoft Corporation as a vendor for 7 years. Vast experience on multiple roles for different groups which include Information Security, Microsoft Education, Microsoft Consulting Services, Windows Mobile, SMS&P and more. Enterprise Search: Worked with multiple enterprise search packages, which include SharePoint 2007 Enterprise Search, FAST ESP and SharePoint 2010. Search Engine Optimization Specialist: Leading the SEO Services for Microsoft Partner Program. process. Also part responsible of creating the baseline report used for analysis. Lead program manager and in charge of closing sales. System Designer: Working as SEO specialist in charge of designing the current automated system to enhance the search engine optimization Entrepreneur as General Manager for IT Company: Responsible for creating the development center for aXelerate inc. in Costa Rica. Lead the entire process from the legal creation of the company, responsible for hiring, purchasing, initial financial management and all responsibilities required to set up the development center and took it profitable state. Dashboard Generation: Helped in the development of systems that provided visibility to management thru the use of Key Performance Indicators. Program Manager: Program manager for multiple projects within aXelerate inc. Use of eScrum, TFS and Microsoft Project. Portal Creation: Responsible for both development and management of portals for Microsoft which include SoftwareBizExchange and InternationalISV. Included design and implementation on top of SharePoint and with Windows Live Security. ASP.Net Security: Developed the security scheme for America’s Network internal website. Used ASP.NET web forms authentication with SQL Server 2000. Replicated the process in Image Photo Studio. 32- to 64-bit Migration Labs: Developed the hands-on labs used currently by Microsoft to guide its partners through the process of migrating applications from 32-bit to 64-bit. Labs have been delivered live in many occasions and taped copies have been distributed as part of resource kit CDs like WinHec 64-bit resource CD. Lead trainer: Delivered the 32- to 64-bit migration hands-on labs for various Microsoft, HP & Intel programs in North America, Europe & Asia. Lead the attendees on the process of upgrading their own applications and provided individual e-mail support. ASP to ASP.NET Automatic Migration: Created a series of automatic analysis tools to estimate project complexity and effort required for migration. From its success, this one man project obtained more resources and the current Microsoft’s ASP to ASP.NET Automatic Migration Tool was created. VB6 to VB.Net Automatic Migration: Worked on the VB Upgrade Wizard that ships with Visual Studio .Net. Researched on ways to further automate the migration process and co-created an analysis tool to estimate effort required for a migration. Also co-created and presented a webcast for MSDN on taking your VB applications beyond migration. Automatic Analysis Tools Developer: Created several small tools used to analyze applications through the use of pattern recognition(pattern-matching) and regular expressions. Objective was to estimate complexity/effort required, or automate fixing specific errors. Upgrading Visual Basic 6.0 Applications to Visual Basic .NET and Visual Basic 2005: Contributed as one of the principal authors of this book. It was developed for the Microsoft’s Patterns & Practices Developer Center and it is available for download on MSDN. BLISS: Part of research for the Business Logic Isolation and Separation initiative. Purpose was to define ways to refactor and re-engineer portions of an application to optimize and enhance legacy applications post-migration. EDUCATION - Computer Science Degree, Costa Rica’s Institute of Technology - Microsoft Certified Professional, Microsoft Certified Technology Specialist - Certified Scrum Master by the Scrum Alliance - Industrial Engineering (Advanced Student), Latin University - Attended many conferences and events: ASP.NET Connections Convention, Visual Studio Training Tour, Microsoft Dev Days, Macromedia events and others. TECHNICAL EXPERTISE Languages: C#, , HTML5, CSS3, Linq, VB.NET, ASP.Net, JQuery, JQuery UI, Silverlight, KendoUI Visual Basic 6, Silverlight, C/C++, Javascript, Prolog & Pascal. Objective C. Technologies: Windows Azure, 32-bit and 64-bit processors (x64 & Itanium), multi-processors system. Windows API (32-bit & 64-bit). Virtualization on HyperV and VMWare. Cloud technologies which include Rackspacecloud, Google Apps and Amazon S3. OSes: Windows Platforms (Windows NT, XP 32-bit & 64-bit, Windows Server 2003 and 2008, Datacenter, Enterprise & 64-bit Editions, PSDK, WinDBG) Databases: Microsoft SQL Server 2012, 2008 & 2005, MySql and SQL Azure. Platforms: .NET Framework 4.0/3.5.2.0, SharePoint 2007 & 2010, Team Foundation Server, SSafe, VisualStudio 6.0/2003/2005, COM/DCOM/COM+, XML, SubVersion, JIRA, Accept360. PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE May 2010 – Current: Development Manager Search Technologies & independent projects - Development manager for a geographically distributed team in the next development phase of a patent research project built on top of ASP.NET and FAST ESP. - Created credit card payment page for MicrosoftPlatformReady.com - Azure presentation application - Mobile CRM application for Account Management Company, for display of progress of lead generation campaigns. - iOS clipboard management application and iOS train schedule. - Project managed using Agile methodologies. JIRA as a bug tracking and release management development aid. - Created several websites & applications as an independent consultant Feb 2009 – May 2010: Scrum Master & Senior Developer Search Technologies - Scrum master & senior developer for a patent research project built on top of SharePoint 2007 and FAST ESP. - Presented a preview of the patent research application at Microsoft’s SharePoint Developers Conference in Las Vegas, NV - Additional presales support for other projects, around SharePoint 2007 and 2010 Nov 2008 – Feb 2009: General Manager, SEO Specialist and Sales Closer. aXelerate inc. – leader of SEO Services for Microsoft Partner Program as Microsoft vendor v-xavmor@microsoft.com - In charge of setting up Microsoft’s SEO initiative for Certified and Gold Certified Partners - Program manager in charge of running the partner program & sales closer in charge of bringing companies on board into the search engine optimization initiative. - SEO analyst providing support for multiple Microsoft Certified Partners on how to increase their online visibility, increase traffic and help manage their marketing efforts. Sept 2006 – Oct 2008: General Manager & Program Manager. aXelerate inc. – working as Microsoft vendor v-xavim@microsoft.com - In charge of handling multiple projects for aXelerate for end customer Microsoft Corporation. Among the projects that lead included: o SoftwareBizExchange: Portal aimed towards the business executive for ISV’s. Project created for the International Association of Microsoft Certified Partners. o InternationalISV: Portal aimed towards certified and gold certified Microsoft partners to take their business international o Course Manager: designed an add on for one of Microsoft Education’s solutions. o And other projects - Helped in the design of several internal applications and worked as senior developer for multiple other projects. April 2006 – Sept 2006: Program Manager. MP Tech Consulting – working as Microsoft vendor v-xavmor@microsoft.com - Program manager for Microsoft Information Security group. In charge of analyzing multiple vendor solutions, and coming up with recommendations over the system to be used to handle high business impact confidential information within Microsoft - Expanded the Business Capability Mapping tool to include a series of key performance indicators for the Industry Solutions Group at Microsoft. Jan 2004 – April 2006: Lead Trainer & Technical Writer. Artinsoft LLC – working as Microsoft vendor v-xavmor@microsoft.com - Team player involved in the development of a series of labs for Microsoft’s Route64.Net initiative to guide developers that need to migrate their code from Windows 32-bit to Windows 64-bit. - Trainer and presenter for the following programs: o Microsoft’s Route64.Net: over 20 labs in Europe, North America and Asia. o HP/Intel Developer Forums: over 10 labs in North America. o Microsoft’s 64Advantage migration lab. o Itanium Solutions Alliance. o Supported various developer labs in Building 20 at Microsoft’s main campus in Redmond. 2003 – 2004: Consultant Artinsoft LLC & Independent contracts - Setup the security scheme for two ASP.NET websites. For both projects, FormsAuthentication security was used with SQL Server 2000 as backend. One of the applications stored images for a Photo Studio while the other one was a small Sharepoint-like web app that stored sensitive private documents that can only be downloaded with the appropriate security privileges. - Minor web site development. Emphasis on programming. - Provided services setting up new web sites. Included the process right from buying domains, setting up DNS, creating and setting up virtual folders, ftp accounts, setting up indexes, creating email accounts and general control panel administration for www.CR-Hosting.com. - Developed and maintained a small system for a multinational company. It processed information on excel sheets, organized and formatted it and then created CSV files that are used as input for a bigger system. - Carried out several POCs where Winforms applications where migrated to Webforms. Sep 2002 – Dec 2003: Presales Engineer ARTINSOFT. Zona Franca. Services and Migrations Department. - MSDN Webcast: Taking Your Microsoft Visual Basic 6.0 Application One Step Beyond Migration. Co-creator and presenter. - Technical documents writing and revision about migration products and related technologies. - System diagnosis and assessments for migration projects. Created the first standardized procedure on how to carry out an assessment. - Performed several POCs from Visual Basic 6 to Visual Basic.Net. - Presentations and demonstrations in technical events and meetings. Sept 2001 – Aug 2002: Consultant ARTINSOFT. S.A. Services and Migrations Department. - Visual Basic 6 to Visual Basic .NET Migration projects development. o Migrated SAFECO’s Personal Lines Rating System, deployed December 2002. (Quarter of a million lines of code) o Successfully migrated e-volution Visualizer system from e-volution Soft. (40.000 lines of code) o Other migrations. - Speaker at various Microsoft events in Costa Rica, Mexico and Puerto Rico. (Up to 800 attendants in biggest event) - College professor at the Latin University of Costa Rica PERSONAL SKILLS: - Self motivated and enthusiastic team player with initiative. - Responsible, reliable and honest. - Good listener with a great learning ability. - Ability to work under pressure but not limited to. - Works great under an organized environment with defined goals; but able to adapt to a flexible environment. LANGUAGES Spanish - Native English - Equal to native

item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded: [11:44:04 AM] Xavier Morera: That is part of my plan [11:44:05 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: things like that [11:44:09 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: yeah, I thought it was [11:44:35 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: but a project like CPA can often hold you back and make it a little too comfortable [11:44:39 AM] Xavier Morera: I know [11:44:46 AM] Xavier Morera: The dreaded comfort zone [11:44:52 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: which, in my case, is the same sort of thinking I'm doing for myself [11:44:54 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: yep [11:44:59 AM] Xavier Morera: Correct [11:45:12 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: I'm right smack in the middle of the comfort zone right now [11:45:24 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: which I think is partially what makes me uncomfortable [11:45:30 AM] Xavier Morera: I've been doing that since day 1 of CPA [11:45:56 AM] Xavier Morera: Remember I had a 24 employee company, as founding partner, two days before joining cpa [11:45:59 AM] Xavier Morera: Discover [11:46:06 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: a good blog post... how do you get out of the comfort zone without changing jobs? [11:46:13 AM] Xavier Morera: I've been working on moving on for quite a while [11:46:35 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: yeah, I know what you mean... the 'working on' part can easily drag on for longer than you might want or expect [11:46:44 AM] Xavier Morera: Yes [11:46:44 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: I have other interests as well [11:46:57 AM] Xavier Morera: at the beginning 99% of my income was CPA [11:47:08 AM] Xavier Morera: Last fiscal year Search Tech accounted for 48% [11:47:09 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: interests that I'm not getting any closer too while at CPA [11:47:21 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: that's interesting [11:47:33 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: surprising in a good way [11:47:43 AM] Xavier Morera: On the blog post, I got approval to publish a guest post in pluralsight, writing it this week [11:47:52 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: very nice [11:48:05 AM] Xavier Morera: It is tiring though [11:48:07 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: maybe I can learn a little from your step in this 'direction' [11:48:32 AM] Xavier Morera: Yeah, anything I can teach but here is a small summary [11:48:38 AM] Xavier Morera: - Work hard, takes long hours [11:48:58 AM] Xavier Morera: - Try ideas, your first ones will be very stupid [11:49:06 AM] Xavier Morera: You keep getting better until eventually people pay you for them [11:49:14 AM] Xavier Morera: Happened with my dealership app [11:49:29 AM] Xavier Morera: - Network and do your best without selling yourself [11:49:50 AM] Xavier Morera: I tried to set up a business with www.dealerlogix.com as distributor, that did not work [11:49:52 AM] Xavier Morera: Got the support center [11:49:57 AM] Xavier Morera: (recurring, stable revenue) [11:50:37 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: recurring revenue always sounds like a good option [11:50:37 AM] Xavier Morera: - Reinvest money you make, it is the way to improve. Even more than saving. Everything from the support center went first to tienda.outdoorscr.com, our outdoor stuff reditribution [11:50:41 AM] Xavier Morera: with my brothers [11:51:11 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: yeah, my brothers and I have tossed around a few ideas but we are not as entrepreneurial as you are [11:51:12 AM] Xavier Morera: - And bootstrap. I have 80 domains in 140 sites. They were originally just to pay for my development environment. They make me a few grand a year [11:51:13 AM] Xavier Morera: hehe [11:51:28 AM] Xavier Morera: - Always do a good, it helps you get more referrals [11:51:34 AM] Xavier Morera: - And be very clear on what you want [11:51:37 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: we're all in IT but very different personalities [11:51:50 AM] Xavier Morera: I wasn't and I lost a lot of time and energy [11:51:50 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: sounds like a good list of driving principles [11:51:53 AM] Xavier Morera: I know now [11:52:03 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: at least you have a list! [11:52:07 AM] Xavier Morera: One problem I had was I always said yes to everything [11:52:17 AM] Xavier Morera: So I was dividing myself in a lot of pieces [11:52:36 AM] Xavier Morera: Now I basically say no every time when I am approached by someone to help them on an app or similar [11:52:40 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: I have the same problem but with learning new things... I can't say no to any new technology area [11:52:43 AM] Xavier Morera: And I really enjoy now saying no [11:52:56 AM] Xavier Morera: oh, and important, it is not about technology [11:52:59 AM] Xavier Morera: it is about solutions [11:53:09 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: yep, I agree [11:53:22 AM] Xavier Morera: Watch Cory' [11:53:24 AM] Xavier Morera: s course [11:53:25 AM] Xavier Morera: http://www.pluralsight.com/training/Courses/Description/career-reboot-for-developer-mind [11:53:30 AM] Xavier Morera: I met him in February [11:53:31 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: I always think about the business connection in day-to-day work, just not with my personal training decisions [11:53:33 AM] Xavier Morera: Great advice [11:53:35 AM] Xavier Morera: Then Dan's [11:53:48 AM] Xavier Morera: http://pluralsight.com/training/courses/TableOfContents?courseName=want-to-be-entrepreneur&highlight=dan-appleman_want-to-be-entrepreneur-m5!dan-appleman_want-to-be-entrepreneur-m8!dan-appleman_want-to-be-entrepreneur-m1!dan-appleman_want-to-be-entrepreneur-m2!dan-appleman_want-to-be-entrepreneur-m4!dan-appleman_want-to-be-entrepreneur-m6!dan-appleman_want-to-be-entrepreneur-m9!dan-appleman_want-to-be-entrepreneur-m3!dan-appleman_want-to-be-entrepreneur-m7#want-to-be-entrepreneur-m5 [11:53:49 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: Dan Wahlin? [11:54:05 AM] Xavier Morera: Appleman [11:54:06 AM] Xavier Morera: http://pluralsight.com/training/courses/TableOfContents?courseName=productivity-tips-busy-tech-professional&highlight= [11:54:07 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: ok [11:54:13 AM] CPA - Chris Fussell: I will check it out [11:54:14 AM] Xavier Morera: And finally this guy [11:54:36 AM] Xavier Morera: It is all work hard, focus, know where you want to go, learn and apply but not for the sake of technology [11:54:39 AM] Xavier Morera: And don't give up [11:54:46 AM] Xavier Morera: every year I make it a little bit more [11:54:49 AM] Xavier Morera: But stil have not arrived [11:54:52 AM] Xavier Morera: Although I am getting there

item.title: How to Mount an NTFS USB Drive in CentOS
item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded:
yum install epel-release
yum install ntfs-3g
mkdir /mnt/win
mount -t ntfs-3g /dev/sdb1 /mnt/win

item.title: Apache Impala
item.dc:creator: viva
item.content:encoded:
The story of Apache Impala

In this post we will give you a nice overview on a widely used and high performing query engine named Apache Impala.

 

To give you a taste of what Apache Impala is capable of, consider that its goal is to handle very complex queries, using the well known and long lived SQL syntax, and responding in mere seconds. 

What is Apache Impala?

Apache Impala is an open source query engine working on Apache Hadoop. Impala allows you to query data using SQL syntax without the usual waiting time you get when using Apache Hive for instance. 

 

Therefore, use Impala when you  want to SQL query petabytes of data stored in Apache Hadoop clusters and you are not in the mood of waiting more than a couple of seconds. Impala lets you handle data in real time, it is as fast as lightning and will let you analyse, transform and bring together data from various data sources.    

 

Impala was developed by Cloudera to get rid of the MapReduce layer that Apache Hive uses. Inspired by Dremel and Drill, they set out to develop something similar. But instead of a Java engine, Cloudera used a native C++ MPP engine. And thus became Impala, giving us fast and efficient Hadoop queries. 


Impala is called a MPP SQL query engine, where the MPP stands for Massive Parallel Processing, a database technology that can process extremely large amounts of data. Apache Impala truly performs exceptionally well and with only a fraction of the amount of waiting time that is required with the other SQL engines in Hadoop. Impala is clearly the highest achiever in the group. So, again, if you want to query Hadoop stored data and get your answers fast, choose
Impala!

What are the advantages of Apache Impala?

It's time to get even more into detail about why Impala is the tool to use when querying big data. It's time to bring awareness to the features that make Impala worth your while!

Ultra high speed

Impala will allow you to process data, stored in HDFS at ultra high speed using the well known SQL language.

No need to transform or migrate data

When you use Impala there is no need to transform or migrate data, because the data processing happens inside the Hadoop cluster.

You only need SQL knowledge

There is no need to know Java because the need for MapReduce has been omitted. The only thing you need is a basic knowledge of SQL

Save time

Before you are able to analyse data with the regular business tools, the data goes through a complex ETL cycle. If we choose Impala we can transcend these time wasting stages and proceed blazingly fast!

Economical

Impala is one of the only tools using the Parquet file format, this is a columnar storage layout that works efficiently for large-scale queries. It greatly reduces time and storage requirements thereby brings down costs!

Highly compatible

With Impala it is just too easy to share data files between the different Hadoop components. There is no need for copy, import or export. Impala has no issues whatsoever with reading or writing on Hive tables.

And lastly, Apache Impala is open source! It is therefore available freely under the Apache license. It´s the native analytic database for Apache Hadoop. Given that Impala is an Apache-licensed open source project it is regarded as exemplar and has a massive community to inspire or help you.

What is Impala used for or what are 6 of it´s key applications?

Let's understand better why Impala is such an innovative tool and used by the world's biggest companies.

A super charged Hadoop BI tool

We can use Impala for handling Business intelligence queries on the Hadoop system. It does this at warp speed and everything simultaneously. Impala scales linearly, keeping the Hadoop advantage of linear scalability. This means we can grow clusters by adding more hardware and are able to confront larger user pools or larger data sets. This is the edge that Hadoop has and is reachable through Apache Impala.

All of of the infrastructure together in one place

We can allocate the same file, data formats and metadata, security, and resource management frameworks to Hadoop. There is no need anymore for a non essential infrastructure or data repetition.

Expect high level security

Because Impala is integrated with native Hadoop security we can be certain that the data will only be available to people that are authorized to use it. 

Open source Software

Impala is open source from an Apache License, therefore it has more flexibility, security and transparency. It is carried by a large community of developers who believe in the open exchange of information and enabling a greater freedom to create better and bigger projects.

Taking Hadoop to infinity and beyond ..

Impala allows for more users to interact with increasingly more data via only one warehouse and metadata store. This is one of the reasons why companies such as Stripe, Agoda, Apple, Expedia,... choose to use Apache Impala!

Beyond regular Business Intelligence

Because Impala answers your SQL queries so extremely fast it brings you to a whole new level of issues to unravel. Since you don't need to reduce data size anymore your analysis will bring more accurate results and will be closer to reality. Working with a highly efficient, easy and fast tool such as Impala, will greatly enhance your love of learning and investigation and will bring massive amounts of inspiration and good vibes!

Impala can allow you to use strategies such as exploratory data analysis and data discovery. This would have been impossible with earlier software.

What are Apache Impala´s weaknesses?

After this overly enthusiastic and positive portrayal of our big data tool of the day, we are obliged to focus a little bit on Impala´s flaws

  • Impala can't support us with Serialization and Deserialization.
  • Impala is only capable of reading text files and not custom binary files.
  • If new records/files are added to the data directory in HDFS, we need to refresh the table.

That's all the negative traits we can think of! Time to go over the reasons again of why Impala is so popular and widely used.

Why again should you use Impala?

Before we end our Apache Impala expose we would like to swiftly go over all the good it has brought to the world of Big Data. In general we can argue that it is the perfect synthesis between the ease of SQL and multi user performance and the scalability and flexibility Apache Hadoop brings. 

 

We can use SQL to access HDFS or HBase faster than Hive or other SQL engines can. Impala can work with a wide variety of file formats that Hadoop uses. Because Impala uses the same metadata, SQL and interface as Hive it offers us a known and unified place to handle batch-oriented or real-time queries. Given that it is not based on MapReduce algorithms like Hive is, Impala is considerably faster than Apache Hive. 

 

All the components of the Hadoop system can share files with each other freely. There is just this one system for big data processing and analytics, no need for unnecessary costs and no precious time wasted.

Conclusion

We hope you realised just how revolutionary and life changing Apache Impala is and why it is used by so many companies all around the world. This open source software has become a very important project carried by many developers all over the world that are continuously improving and upgrading this magnificent tool.

Because Impala is integrated with native Hadoop security we can be certain that the data will only be available to people that are authorized to use it.\u00a0 <\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"26bddfa","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"4ae0527","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"78bb503","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Open source Software","header_size":"h3"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"1f606ce","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"0eadd2b","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"b56d92e","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Impala is open source from an Apache License, therefore it has more flexibility, security and transparency. It is carried by a large community of developers who believe in the open exchange of information and enabling a greater freedom to create better and bigger projects. <\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"3c67b05","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"13216c4","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"147f7db","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Taking Hadoop to infinity and beyond ..","header_size":"h3"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"446458d","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"df59991","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"8d28425","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Impala allows for more users to interact with increasingly more data via only one warehouse and metadata store. This is one of the reasons why companies such as Stripe, Agoda, Apple, Expedia,... choose to use Apache Impala!<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"7fac71c","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"affe621","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"601807f","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Beyond regular Business Intelligence","header_size":"h3"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"27b565e","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"c6dbdc9","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"d46a707","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Because Impala answers your SQL queries so extremely fast it brings you to a whole new level of issues to unravel. Since you don't need to reduce data size anymore your analysis will bring more accurate results and will be closer to reality. Working with a highly efficient, easy and fast tool such as Impala, will greatly enhance your love of learning and investigation and will bring massive amounts of inspiration and good vibes!<\/span><\/p>

Impala can allow you to use strategies such as exploratory data analysis and data discovery. This would have been impossible with earlier software.<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"e8458e1","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"2973120","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"1509774","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"What are Apache Impala\u00b4s weaknesses?"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"3bb2edf","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"5940489","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"2a2831d","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

After this overly enthusiastic and positive portrayal of our big data tool of the day, we are obliged to focus a little bit on Impala\u00b4s flaws<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"f659449","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"d1e63bf","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"6c61409","elType":"widget","settings":{"icon_list":[{"text":"Impala can't support us with Serialization and Deserialization.","selected_icon":{"value":"fas fa-times","library":"fa-solid"},"_id":"738f3d9"},{"text":"Impala is only capable of reading text files and not custom binary files.","selected_icon":{"value":"fas fa-times","library":"fa-solid"},"_id":"a4d0597"},{"text":"If new records\/files are added to the data directory in HDFS, we need to refresh the table.","selected_icon":{"value":"fas fa-times","library":"fa-solid"},"_id":"b7852cc"}]},"elements":[],"widgetType":"icon-list"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"7f25c2e","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"de296f3","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"3b811c5","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

That's all the negative traits we can think of! Time to go over the reasons again of why Impala is so popular and widely used.<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"f213312","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"457119d","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"23c3d03","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Why again should you use Impala?"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"51ac17c","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"8c5a0d3","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"7bb444e","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Before we end our Apache Impala expose we would like to swiftly go over all the good it has brought to the world of Big Data. In general we can argue that it is the perfect synthesis between the ease of SQL and multi user performance and the scalability and flexibility Apache Hadoop brings.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>

\u00a0<\/p>

We can use SQL to access HDFS or HBase faster than Hive or other SQL engines can. Impala can work with a wide variety of file formats that Hadoop uses. Because Impala uses the same metadata, SQL and interface as Hive it offers us a known and unified place to handle batch-oriented or real-time queries. Given that it is not based on MapReduce algorithms like Hive is, Impala is considerably faster than Apache Hive.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>

\u00a0<\/p>

All the components of the Hadoop system can share files with each other freely. There is just this one system for big data processing and analytics, no need for unnecessary costs and no precious time wasted. <\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"94c138f","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"36aa78f","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"d988224","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Conclusion"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"03f37d4","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"6ce7f8b","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"7cf42b8","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

We hope you realised just how revolutionary and life changing Apache Impala is and why it is used by so many companies all around the world. This open source software has become a very important project carried by many developers all over the world that are continuously improving and upgrading this magnificent tool. <\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false}]

item.title: Apache Solr
item.dc:creator: viva
item.content:encoded:
What is Apache Solr used for?

Solr is an open source, extremely fast and widely used search platform. Some of the world's biggest companies work with Solr. It is used for social media, for instance Linkedin uses it; science and research, Nasa works with Solr for its Nebula Cloud Computing Platform and for search engines, such as Google Search Appliance. Solr is thus behind the search and navigation features of various highly popular internet sites. 

 

So what makes Solr so widely used by companies like Apple, Netflix, Instagram, NASA, Zappos, Goldman Sachs, The White House and many more?

Well, one of the reasons is that Solr can use structured, semi-structured and unstructured data from various sources. It is able to index it and get it ready for almost perfect real - time search. But Solr has more to offer than highly performant search features. Solr also has some pretty potent analytical skills. For example, Solr can be used to get intelligent product recommendations on e-commerce websites, think of the features “Best sellers,” “Recommendations for you,” “Popular right now,” “Trending now,” and “New Releases.”

 

Solr is able to create these because it has the necessary metadata to do it. It can take care of massive amounts of transactions and an excessively high amount of updates. A company can also locate customer segments by putting customer data in Solr and querying it. Solr is able to get you a subset from a gigantic list only from a couple of criteria that you put out. 

 

So, next to having epic search features, Solr can act as an outstanding data store to use for analytical tasks. To be clear, it offers some very advanced search and analytics possibilities in any domain. Companies can effortlessly forge Solr´s flexible features to accommodate their specific needs. Solr can be used for searching DNA patterns, identifying website hackers, matching candidates to jobs or finding your soulmate! And more and more applications are created every day.

Why is Apache Solr so fast?

Solr is lightning fast because it searches for an index and doesn´t search the text directly. Consider the example of finding pages in a book by looking at the index at the back, this will save you a lot of time then when you would go through the whole book page by page. So instead of a page centric data structure there is a keyword data structure.

Can Apache Solr be used as a database?

We can use Solr with Hadoop. Considering that Hadoop tackles massive amounts of data, Solr can easily retrieve the information we need even on this level. We mentioned previously that we can also use Solr for storage purposes. Solr can act like a NoSQL database, or a non relational data storage with analytical features. Solr is therefore both a search and a storage engine that works perfectly well with vast amounts of information.

What are Apache Solr´s top features?

Let´s shine some more light on Solr´s epic features. 

Well, it can search full text, quickly find words or phrases in your data, do dimensional search, real time indexing, dynamic clustering, database integration, work with rich documents (such as word or pdf) and much much more. Solr is able to handle changes in size or scale, and it keeps operating in the event of failure with automated recovery. 

Used by oh so many and updated and developed by a whole bunch of developers and enthusiasts. 

But hold on, what does Solr actually mean? The letters stand for ¨Search on Lucene and Resin¨. Solr is built using Lucene core. Great but what is Lucene? Apache Lucene is a  Java library providing powerful indexing and search features. Because Solr is built using the Lucene core it can use all the specifics of Lucene. But with Solr you don´t need to use your existing or non existing Java skills as you do with Lucene. With Solr the applications in big data are simply endless. 

6 reasons to use Solr or 6 reasons why we like Apache Solr so much?

We would like to end this Solr expose with some of its great attributes to add clarity and make you explicitly aware of how valuable this cute little and extremely useful open source gem is.

High level Full-Text Search masteries

The search is almost real time, on different kinds of data, in various ways and with endless applicability.

Extensive User Interfaces

Solr comes with a really useful interface that will assist you with all your administrative work or search queries.

Easy to adapt to anything we want

We can use Solr for any needs we might have with our data and on any size of data we want to work on.

Massive corpus or Extensible Plugins

Again making sure we can adapt Solr to any of our needs, it comes with easy to use extension points.

Ready to wear Security

Various security hazards are taken care of such as SSL encryption, authentication and users or role authorization.

Fun oversight

Solr has many tools we can use to supervise its metrics, commercial or open source

Conclusion

We wanted to give you a light overview on Apache Solr, what is it, where is it used and why is it so valuable. Because it is open source and considered as a top priority project it is updated and developed continuously. The applications of Solr are so diverse and so pervasive and new and exciting ways to use Solr are created nearly every day. Thereby greatly improving the way we look at, work with and act upon the world in various domains.

item.title: A light on HBase
item.dc:creator: viva
item.content:encoded:
A simple guide to Apache HBase

Now: In a previous post we featured Apache Hadoop. Two big disadvantages of Hadoop is that it cannot handle writes and reads at a very high speed and it cannot change a file without fully rewriting it. Luckily we have HBase to help us solve these issues. Apache HBase is a NoSQL database constructed on Hadoop. Apache HBase enables random writes and reads fastly and as efficiently as possible. Furthermore HBase is capable of handling exponentially growing data, giving us all the scalability and partitioning we need to arrive at highly efficient storage and retrieval capabilities. Get ready for your essential and easy guide to Apache HBase!

You might be wondering: “What is Apache HBase, in more detail?”.

Just like many of the other Big Data tools we featured in previous posts, HBase is an open source and top level project used by many of the world's leading companies. Netflix, Pinterest, Yahoo, Spotify and Facebook messenger use Apache HBase (Facebook started using something else in 2018).  Because these websites introduce new applications used by billions of people daily, they need databases that can manage large traffic spikes. Relational Databases just can't handle this, that is why these companies started using database management systems that could tackle data in a non relational way. Hence the origin of Apache HBase. 

 

Apache HBase was inspired by Google's Bigtable, is written in Java, and can store large amounts of sparse data without being vulnerable to errors. As mentioned earlier, it is designed to be used on real time data processing or for random read or write access to large quantities of data. 

 

It is a non relational data store that scales linearly. Non relational databases alter the traditional table form of rows and columns, they use specialized structures to store data. 

When using HBase we predefine the table schema and we specify the column families, with the possibility of adding new columns whenever we want providing us with both flexibility as well as adaptability.

How does it work? How to “Apache HBase?”.

In HBase the data is stored in individual columns, and unique row keys index the data. Because of this, individual rows and columns can be found in no time and we can enjoy efficient scans over individual columns within a table. We have all the data and our requests circulating across all servers in an HBase cluster. This is why we are able to query results on petabytes of data instantly.

What are the advantages of Apache HBase?

Now, we have etched out the basic what and why of Apache HBase. We thought it would be fun and useful to cover the advantages of HBase in more detail. 

 

HBase´s main advantages are scalability, fault tolerance and the fact that it executes everything extremely fast. Combined with a strong security, operational simplicity and a low cost of ownership, we now understand why it is used by so many leading companies. 

Scalable

It was made to be able to manage scaling throughout a multitude of servers and the handling of access to petabytes of data. It has no problem whatsoever in dealing with online access to enormous data sets.

Fast as lightning

HBase makes it possible to random read and write access to massive amounts of data in almost no time because it allocates requests from applications throughout a cluster of hosts. 

Each of these hosts can enter the data in HDFS and deal with read and write requests in split seconds.

Insensitive to errors

It can share data stored in tables throughout various hosts in the cluster and is made to keep functioning independent of failures in one of the individual hosts. 

 

Why don’t we take a closer look at how Apache HBase accomplishes these things, what is it´s basic architecture? How is it able to do the things it does so fast and efficiently?

How is the HBase architecture set up?

HBase architecture consists of  a single HBase master node and several slaves or region servers. Each region server takes care of a set of regions where each region can only be served by one region server. The HMaster sends a received request to the region server that deals with that particular region.

HMaster

This master is in charge of the following tasks:

  • Handling and observing of the Hadoop Cluster
  • It is the UI for creating, updating and deleting tables.
  • Assigning the requests
  • Defining the data structures
  • Assisting the user with schema changes or any adaptations to the metadata operations

Region Server

These are the worker nodes in the set up. They do everything from reading, writing, updating to deleting clients ́requests. They work on HDFS DataNode and have the next elements:

  • Block Cache: Here we can find the read data. Read data is put in the read cache. When this is full, data is deleted.
  • MemStore: This has the write cache, it will store new data that we don´t have on the disk yet. A memstore is attached to each column family in a region.
  • The WAL, also known as Write Ahead Log, which is essentially a file that will gather new data that will not be permanently curated.
  • The HFile or the storage file staches away the rows as sorted key values on a disk.

Zookeeper

The ZooKeeper coordinates region tasks and comes to the rescue when any of the region servers crashes. It will distribute the work to region servers that are still functioning.The ZooKeeper is a server that upholds all the information on the configuration and keeps everything working as a functional integrated whole. The Zookeeper is the gateway to the regions. The Zookeeper decides if you can connect with the HMaster and the region servers. Whenever there is an error with one of the nodes in a HBase cluster the Zookeeper will fix the issues.

 

The zookeeper takes notes on the quantity of region servers and the ones that have the DataNode. HMaster will turn to the Zookeeper to get to know the region servers. So, this one basically takes care of the communication, the maintenance, the error identification and the management of configuration information.

How is data stored in HBase?

Because HBase is a columnar database all data is stored into tables with rows and columns. This is just like in relational database management systems (RDBMSs) with the difference that each of the cells in HBase have a “version” characteristic. This makes it possible to identify each particular cell. This versioning keeps track of changes in the cell, enabling retrieval. The data is stored in decreasing order; this means that we will always find the latest value of each cell. 

 

The columns in HBase are each part of a column family. The column family name is important to know what family a particular member belongs to. So for example, pandas and tigers belong to the animal column family.

 

A key is assigned to every row in the HBase tables, it will enable us to manage the access to the cells in the rows. The schema consists of all of these characteristics, we need to establish it before we can store any data. But we can always afterwards change tables or add new column families. This is as you know an essential trait when dealing with big data! 

Hbase is used a lot with the internet of things, fraud detection applications, product catalogs, playlists, messaging apps, machine learning model serving and much much more!

Conclusion

Apache HBase was released in 2008 and developed to process massive amounts of data. The beauty of it is that it can be used for real time data processing or for random read or write access to large quantities of data. 

 

This non relational database has a predefined table schema where we specify the column families, with the possibility of adding new columns whenever we want providing us with both flexibility as well as adaptability. 

 

Many enterprises use Apache HBase because of its scalability, fault tolerance, lightning fast execution, strong security, operational simplicity and its low cost of ownership. It is open source, built on HDFS and is considered as a Apache Top - Level Project, being improved and updated continuously!

[{"id":"41352e5e","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"5121fbd2","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"e14f44c","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"A simple guide to Apache HBase","header_size":"h1"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"797348e2","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"31ddf713","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"65485ecb","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Now: In a previous post we featured Apache Hadoop. Two big disadvantages of Hadoop is that it cannot handle writes and reads at a very high speed and it cannot change a file without fully rewriting it. Luckily we have HBase to help us solve these issues. Apache HBase is a NoSQL database constructed on Hadoop. Apache HBase enables random writes and reads fastly and as efficiently as possible. Furthermore HBase is capable of handling exponentially growing data, giving us all the scalability and partitioning we need to arrive at highly efficient storage and retrieval capabilities. Get ready for your essential and easy guide to Apache HBase! <\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"504ca24e","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"6d22e31c","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"2363c532","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"You might be wondering: \u201cWhat is Apache HBase, in more detail?\u201d."},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"16813233","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"2f0986ed","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"678e52ea","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Just like many of the other Big Data tools we featured in previous posts, HBase is an open source and top level project used by many of the world's leading companies. Netflix, Pinterest, Yahoo, Spotify and Facebook messenger use Apache HBase (Facebook started using something else in 2018).\u00a0 Because these websites introduce new applications used by billions of people daily, they need databases that can manage large traffic spikes. Relational Databases just can't handle this, that is why these companies started using database management systems that could tackle data in a non relational way. Hence the origin of Apache HBase.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>

\u00a0<\/p>

Apache HBase was inspired by Google's Bigtable, is written in Java, and can store large amounts of sparse data without being vulnerable to errors. As mentioned earlier, it is designed to be used on real time data processing or for random read or write access to large quantities of data.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>

\u00a0<\/p>

It is a non relational data store that scales linearly. Non relational databases alter the traditional table form of rows and columns, they use specialized structures to store data.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>

When using HBase we predefine the table schema and we specify the column families, with the possibility of adding new columns whenever we want providing us with both flexibility as well as adaptability.<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"2284d786","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"30d3f08a","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"3cf0d120","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"How does it work? How to \u201cApache HBase?\u201d."},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"774c81ce","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"3047bfad","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"60cef0f0","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

In HBase the data is stored in individual columns, and unique row keys index the data. Because of this, individual rows and columns can be found in no time and we can enjoy efficient scans over individual columns within a table. We have all the data and our requests circulating across all servers in an HBase cluster. This is why we are able to query results on petabytes of data instantly.<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"28d08490","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"35037d2b","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"4f6b60d1","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"What are the advantages of Apache HBase?"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"7b4db6dd","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"6127653","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"596b2726","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Now, we have etched out the basic what and why of Apache HBase. We thought it would be fun and useful to cover the advantages of HBase in more detail.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>

\u00a0<\/p>

HBase\u00b4s main advantages are scalability, fault tolerance and the fact that it executes everything extremely fast. Combined with a strong security, operational simplicity and a low cost of ownership, we now understand why it is used by so many leading companies.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"4390cbf","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"efdcd75","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"2929890","elType":"widget","settings":{"tabs":[{"tab_title":"Scalable","tab_content":"

It was made to be able to manage scaling throughout a multitude of servers and the handling of access to petabytes of data. It has no problem whatsoever in dealing with online access to enormous data sets. <\/span><\/p>","_id":"47caed0"},{"tab_title":"Fast as lightning","tab_content":"

HBase makes it possible to random read and write access to massive amounts of data in almost no time because it allocates requests from applications throughout a cluster of hosts.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>

Each of these hosts can enter the data in HDFS and deal with read and write requests in split seconds.<\/span><\/p>","_id":"dee7476"},{"_id":"9fc006a","tab_title":"Insensitive to errors","tab_content":"

It can share data stored in tables throughout various hosts in the cluster and is made to keep functioning independent of failures in one of the individual hosts.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>

\u00a0<\/p>

Why don't we take a closer look at how Apache HBase accomplishes these things, what is it\u00b4s basic architecture? How is it able to do the things it does so fast and efficiently?<\/span><\/p>"}]},"elements":[],"widgetType":"toggle"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"10fbd8c","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"42b11e7a","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"70944d48","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"How is the HBase architecture set up?"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"7ce35007","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"3319ba88","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"74b3b4e6","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

HBase architecture consists of\u00a0 a single HBase master node and several slaves or region servers. Each region server takes care of a set of regions where each region can only be served by one region server. The HMaster sends a received request to the region server that deals with that particular region. <\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"af62d63","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"026a11a","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"55a303f","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"HMaster","header_size":"h3"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"c86c36f","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"7fe51d4","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"3a8ad0d","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

This master is in charge of the following tasks:<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"d130059","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"3269407","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"86b9ecc","elType":"widget","settings":{"icon_list":[{"text":"Handling and observing of the Hadoop Cluster","_id":"52cc69c"},{"text":"It is the UI for creating, updating and deleting tables. ","_id":"36bc6fc"},{"text":"Assigning the requests","_id":"ec72691"},{"_id":"aeb36cd","text":"Defining the data structures"},{"_id":"03eac49","text":"Assisting the user with schema changes or any adaptations to the metadata operations"}]},"elements":[],"widgetType":"icon-list"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"a4d7f59","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"16af8c2","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"c579a95","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Region Server","header_size":"h3"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"77acb96","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"2e3629f","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"ebef7f6","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

These are the worker nodes in the set up. They do everything from reading, writing, updating to deleting clients \u0301requests. They work on HDFS DataNode and have the next elements:<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"883b7ac","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"fd6bc7a","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"52e0f64","elType":"widget","settings":{"icon_list":[{"text":"Block Cache: Here we can find the read data. Read data is put in the read cache. When this is full, data is deleted. ","selected_icon":{"value":"far fa-smile","library":"fa-regular"},"_id":"781079a"},{"text":"MemStore: This has the write cache, it will store new data that we don\u00b4t have on the disk yet. A memstore is attached to each column family in a region. ","selected_icon":{"value":"far fa-smile-beam","library":"fa-regular"},"_id":"24915a1"},{"text":"The WAL, also known as Write Ahead Log, which is essentially a file that will gather new data that will not be permanently curated.","selected_icon":{"value":"far fa-smile-wink","library":"fa-regular"},"_id":"cfd8472"},{"_id":"d13dbe5","text":"The HFile or the storage file staches away the rows as sorted key values on a disk.","selected_icon":{"value":"fas fa-smile","library":"fa-solid"}}]},"elements":[],"widgetType":"icon-list"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"2738c46","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"cd52a36","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"442bf55","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Zookeeper","header_size":"h3"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"ce9ebc8","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"a08e035","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"dbeb864","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

The ZooKeeper coordinates region tasks and comes to the rescue when any of the region servers crashes. It will distribute the work to region servers that are still functioning.The ZooKeeper is a server that upholds all the information on the configuration and keeps everything working as a functional integrated whole. The Zookeeper is the gateway to the regions. The Zookeeper decides if you can connect with the HMaster and the region servers. Whenever there is an error with one of the nodes in a HBase cluster the Zookeeper will fix the issues.<\/span><\/p>

\u00a0<\/p>

The zookeeper takes notes on the quantity of region servers and the ones that have the DataNode. HMaster will turn to the Zookeeper to get to know the region servers. So, this one basically takes care of the communication, the maintenance, the error identification and the management of configuration information.<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"d2f742c","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"79cfbf5","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"ccbba4c","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"How is data stored in HBase?"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"b62e714","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"0178fb2","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"ecbd52b","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Because HBase is a columnar database all data is stored into tables with rows and columns. This is just like in relational database management systems (RDBMSs) with the difference that each of the cells in HBase have a \u201cversion\u201d characteristic. This makes it possible to identify each particular cell. This versioning keeps track of changes in the cell, enabling retrieval.
