A key is assigned to every row in the HBase tables, it will enable us to manage the access to the cells in the rows.<\/span> The schema<\/b> consists of all of these characteristics, we need to establish it before we can store any data. But we can always afterwards change tables or add new column families. This is as you know an essential trait when dealing with big data!\u00a0<\/span><\/p>

item.title: All about HDFS
item.dc:creator: viva
item.content:encoded:
The compact and easy guide to HDFS architecture

What is HDFS in Hadoop?

You might be wondering what HDFS stands for and why it exists? HDFS or Hadoop Distributed File System can manage large data sets on just commodity hardware. It will scale a single Apache Hadoop cluster to hundreds or thousands of nodes. HDFS is considered as the primary data storage system used by Hadoop applications. You might remember our post on Apache HBase, a column oriented non relational database control system. Well, HBase works on top of HDFS and improves the real- time data processing. 

What are the goals of HDFS?

HDFS is a system that stores and distributes files in the Hadoop network. Hadoop has a user interface that allows us to interact with HDFS. HDFS has built in servers Name Node and DataNode that help us to check the state of the cluster with ease.

Automatic and fast recovery

HDFS is able to store massive amounts of data and makes the access as easy as possible. 

It can store massive data because the files are stacked across various machines. Files are saved in a redundant way so that there will not be any data lost whenever there might be a breakdown. The recovery from hardware failures is fast just because it was designed to signal errors and commit automatic restoration.

Access to event stream processing

HDFS is meant primarily for batch processing and not exactly interactive use. Therefore it was created to execute high data flow rates, something that is totally compatible with streaming access to data sets.

Taking care of extremely large data sets

HDFS can host applications with data in the range of gigabytes to terabytes. HDFS provides scaling to hundreds of nodes in a single cluster.

Easy to move

HDFS is made to be transported to various hardware platforms and can work with a wide variety of operation systems.

Why do we use multiple data nodes to store information in HDFS?

HDFS is composed of NameNodes and DataNodes. Each NameNode looks where data is stored in the cluster of servers, or DataNodes. All the data is put in data blocks on these nodes. HDFS replicates these blocks and spreads them so they are readily available in the various nodes across the cluster.

What kind of information is stored in the NameNode?

Here´s the deal, the NameNode is the highlight of HDFS. Every single NameNode only gathers  the metadata of HDFS, the index structure of all the files in the system and monitors everything across the cluster. Here is the best part, it doesn't actually store the data. This work is done by the DataNodes. NameNodes record the metadata information of the files stored in the cluster (on the DataNodes), such as the location of blocks stored, the file size, permissions, hierarchy and more.

How to write a file to all data nodes in HDFS?

We do this by using a NameNode to get the location of the Datanodes on which to write the data. We can write the data directly on the DataNode, it will create a pipeline to start writing data on. And the NameNode manages all these DataNodes. So, the NameNode does things like locating, opening, closing  and renaming files and directories.

How HDFS is different from other file systems?

Although HDFS is pretty similar to other distributed file systems it does offer some nice advantages that most of them lack. Just consider that it is extremely fault tolerant and can be used on considerably low cost hardware.

Time to review the top features of HDFS

Hadoop is used by over 339 companies, among them we find well known companies such as Uber, Airbnb, and Pinterest. Looking at its goals and top features we understand why it is such a widely used big data tool!

Cost effective and Scalable

HDFS can be used on most of the regular hardware. And more nodes can be added whenever we want, making HDFS indeed scalable.

Variety and Volume of Data

We said it before; HDFS can store massive amounts of data; Terabytes & Petabytes of data. It doesn’t matter if it is structured, unstructured or semi structured, HDFS is able to take care of it!

Reliability and Fault Tolerance

HDFS puts the given data into data blocks, replicates it and keeps it in a distributed mode across the Hadoop cluster. Fostering reliability and fault tolerance.

The value of data redundancy

Because HDFS saves files in a redundant way it obviously increases availability of data. By breaking up a large volume of work into smaller pieces so that it can be done across all the servers, high scalability and data locality is achieved, totally useful when working with big data!

Conclusion

Looking at HDFS many advantages and key attributes it is easy to understand why it used by oh so many companies. It is extremely fault tolerant and can be used on considerably low cost hardware, furthermore it is compatible with a wide variety of operation systems. 

It can manage enormously large data sets on just commodity hardware. This is why HDFS is considered as the primary data storage system used by Hadoop applications. 

And because we can add extra nodes whenever we want, HDFS is definitely scalable. HDFS can store massive amounts of data; Terabytes & Petabytes of data. And it doesn't even matter if it is structured, unstructured or semi structured data. HDFS excels and thrives all over!

This ends our expose on HDFS, we brought together the main advantages and architecture of HDFS and gave you a brief insight on this important element in the Hadoop network.

And the NameNode manages all these DataNodes. So, the NameNode does things like locating, opening, closing\u00a0 and renaming files and directories. <\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"dd7df97","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"d196aeb","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"5dd9e4a","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"How HDFS is different from other file systems?"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"d34f30b","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"9316a43","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"01f9c88","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Although HDFS is pretty similar to other distributed file systems it does offer some nice advantages that most of them lack. Just consider that it is extremely fault tolerant and can be used on considerably low cost hardware.<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"5c6ccea","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"1254f7c","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"5e54722","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Time to review the top features of HDFS"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"a3dd646","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"ada65a1","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"7889266","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Hadoop is used by over 339 companies, among them we find well known companies such as Uber, Airbnb, and Pinterest. Looking at its goals and top features we understand why it is such a widely used big data tool!<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"2b58e89","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"a98b9dd","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"18538d3","elType":"widget","settings":{"tabs":[{"tab_title":"Cost effective and Scalable","tab_content":"

HDFS can be used on most of the regular hardware. And more nodes can be added whenever we want, making HDFS indeed scalable.<\/span><\/p>","_id":"089a577"},{"tab_title":"Variety and Volume of Data","tab_content":"

We said it before; HDFS can store massive amounts of data; Terabytes & Petabytes of data. It doesn't matter if it is structured, unstructured or semi structured, HDFS is able to take care of it!<\/span><\/p>","_id":"7f14b6d"},{"_id":"afbcd15","tab_title":"Reliability and Fault Tolerance","tab_content":"

HDFS puts the given data into data blocks, replicates it and keeps it in a distributed mode across the Hadoop cluster. Fostering reliability and fault tolerance.<\/span><\/p>"},{"_id":"cdf5af6","tab_title":"The value of data redundancy","tab_content":"

Because HDFS saves files in a redundant way it obviously increases availability of data. By breaking up a large volume of work into smaller pieces so that it can be done across all the servers, high scalability and data locality is achieved, totally useful when working with big data!<\/span><\/p>"}]},"elements":[],"widgetType":"toggle"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"45285c24","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"3d7beaee","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"45b5dfaa","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Conclusion"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"542f422","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"159bcf22","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"1d1004d6","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Looking at HDFS many advantages and key attributes it is easy to understand why it used by oh so many companies. It is extremely fault tolerant and can be used on considerably low cost hardware, furthermore it is compatible with a wide variety of operation systems. <\/span><\/p>\n

It can manage enormously large data sets on just commodity hardware. This is why HDFS is considered as the primary data storage system used by Hadoop applications. <\/span><\/p>

And because we can add extra nodes whenever we want, HDFS is definitely scalable. HDFS can store massive amounts of data; Terabytes & Petabytes of data. And it doesn't even matter if it is structured, unstructured or semi structured data. HDFS excels and thrives all over!<\/span><\/p>\n

This ends our expose on HDFS, we brought together the main advantages and architecture of HDFS and gave you a brief insight on this important element in the Hadoop network.<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false}]

item.title: The cloud
item.dc:creator: viva
item.content:encoded:
“What is the Cloud and Why Should I Care?”

Yes, what is the Cloud, when did it originate, how did it get started and why should you care? The association with the word cloud is no longer that white fluffy thing in the sky that you can stare at and will inspire you to see various animals and situations. No, the association people have nowadays when hearing this word is linked to the internet. More specifically, a place online where you can manage all of your data, somewhat like an online, ever expanding hard disk.

In this post we focus on the three best known and most used cloud service providers, namely AWS, Azure and GCP or amazon, microsoft and google clouds. 

 

Before we go into all three of them in more detail lets review why they are useful and so prevalent in our society nowadays. Cloud services fulfill four essential and life enhancing goals. 

 

More specifically; Accessibility, convenience, affordability and elasticity. By using these services your data will be available from any device, in an easy and stress free way. Moreover, you will be able to save money compared to buying your own hard disks and you can always upgrade to a bigger storage space if you need to.

 

In short, cloud infrastructures are in big demand and used all over. But out of what needs and when did they arise and why should you use AWS, Azure or GCP? We seek to get you the insights on these questions in the following pages! Enjoy your immersion into the beginnings and current state of the world's leading cloud service providers! 

AWS or Amazone´s cloud

Lets jump right into AWS also known as Amazon's cloud. AWS has grown into, by the time of writing this post, the most successful cloud infrastructure on earth! Casting a shadow on all the other cloud infrastructure companies, even surpassing the popularity of the cloud services offered by Google, Microsoft and IBM.

Amazon Web Services was at the start of its cloud computing platform. It started as a developer tool in 2002, offering SOAP and XML interfaces for all the products Amazon had to offer. Amazon saw that the infrastructure services they had at that time was their biggest asset. So they came up with the brilliant idea of combining their infrastructure services and developer tools to have a quasi-operating system for the internet.

 

They developed an infrastructure consisting of computational power, storage and a database with tools to manage these. In 2006, AWS went public as a Simple Storage Service and Elastic Compute Cloud. Around 2009 AWS was fully functional and very attractive to the major massive data using companies such as netflix, dropbox or reddit.

Now, why should you use AWS?

AWS aims to give companies the opportunity to run their technology application on the AWS platform.

Given that AWS offers extensive elastic computational abilities it is frequently used by data scientists. It seems that the API´s in AWS are out of this world, and usually the preferred choice of many tech based companies. And because AWS is a low cost service provider that can help you with almost all of your data needs, many companies opt for AWS. Its scaling capabilities are also superior in many ways. 

 

It is cheap, anyone can use AWS services without any expensive upfront costs and at an hourly price if needed. AWS upholds the values of the retail company that started it, with price cuts, only developing technologies when there is a demand, and being mindful of the ever evolving needs of their users. 

 

AWS´cloud is extremely big, Amazon can see the variety of jobs that are being run on it and it is able to act according to the customer demands they can see. Because it is so extensive it has unparalleled research and development possibilities. Because of AWS´ scaling capabilities many other benefits spring forth, such as the previously mentioned low pricing, extensive geographical reach, and an inspirational research and development hub. 

 

Application and more advantages of AWS

AWS is perfect for people with avoidant attachment styles, there is no need to commit, you pay per hour and the moment you stop you won't get charged and there is no start fee required. You can host your website, set up email services, or use Hadoop all on AWS without the fear of being trapped in an exclusive committed relationship.

If you need a new server AWS can deliver within seconds and without the need to buy various licences. 

 

Using AWS will also eliminate any fear issues you might have. Its security features are definitely elaborate. The AWS infrastructure is highly secure, with guarded and limited authorization data centers and designed to withstand many system failures. 

AWS is flexible and its auto scaling will create for you a self managing infrastructure based on your companies data needs. 

 

AWS helps to create companies fast and ready to act on market demands, saving you time and resources and getting you in business the easiest, cheapest and fastest way possible. For instance many famous online games use AWS, offering flexible scalability in the case of sudden increases or drops in popularity. 

 

Now we dived into the world of AWS. How about checking out Microsoft's Azure, how did Microsoft come up with their Azure and what are its applications and advantages?

 

The cloud of Microsoft that is Azure

Microsoft Azure was released in 2010, Microsoft initially wanted to offer 5 different cloud service on Azure:

  • Microsoft SQL Services for databases
  • Computation, storage and networking
  • Microsoft .NET Services for developers
  • Live Services for file sharing
  • Microsoft SharePoint Services and Microsoft Dynamics CRM Services SaaS offerings

In essence Azure is a public computing platform, with IaaS (infrastructure), PaaS (platform) and SaaS (software) as a service. These can be used for an extensive variety of needs. Azure is compatible with various programming languages, tools and frameworks and even ventures into the open source world.

Here you can see an overview of most of the things Azure´s can help you with:

  • Computation
  • Networking
  • Storage 
  • Web + Mobile 
  • Containers 
  • Databases 
  • Data + Analytics
  • AI + Cognitive Services 
  • Internet of Things 
  • Enterprise Integration 
  • Security + Identity 
  • Developer Tools 
  • Monitoring + Management 
  • Microsoft Azure Stack

When to use Azure and what are some of its advantages?

Azure is definitely easy to set up and use for companies that are already using Microsoft software. But Microsoft does enable hybrid computing. 

Furthermore, Azure is really proud of its security and compliance capabilities, making it very attractive to governmental agencies.

Similar to AWS, Azure´s services are flexible, highly compatible with any OS, language or tool, reliable, global and seriously economical. 

Azure offers the same features as AWS, lets go over them in some more detail:

Get backup and high failure recovery

Given that Azure has a high degree of flexibility, instantaneous site recovery and excelling integration, it offers the perfect data recovery tool.  

With flexibility we mean that Azure can back up your data in any programming language, wherever you are and whatever OS you are currently working on. Flexibility also entails that you can decide how often and how much you do backups. The cost of setting this up and maintaining it is minimal

Web and Mobile Apps

Azure can host, create and manage your web or mobile app. Saving you time, money and effort with Autoscale features, effortless integration and robust security measures.

Allocate and augment Active Directory

Azure can merge with your Active Directory offering you the possibility to manage everything in one place and at high level security, access to all your tools will be centralized with Azure and it offers many ways in which you can effortlessly decide who has access to all these tools.

Excel with IoT Industry possibilities

You can have an overview on all of your data to get inspired and improve your activities in various ways and in various domains at low cost and with minimal time expenditure. Furthermore because Azure has high level security measures in place you can have more peace of mind when using IoT solutions.

Now that we have set out some of the major benefits cloud services offer, we still want to showcase Google's cloud, which we will do in the next paragraphs.

What can the Google Cloud Platform (GCP) do?

Here’s the deal Google Cloud Platform (GCP) entails a variety of  cloud computing services. GCP arised from the Google App Engine framework meant for hosting web applications from Google's data centers. Google App Engine went public in 2008 and developed into GCP, it is considered as one of the supreme cloud computing platforms available. Even though it doesn't have the same market share as AWS or Azure it does keep in short distance from them and will probably eventually get to their level.

Google App Engine was a platform to build and host apps on the Google frame and eventually led to the Google Cloud Platform in 2013. Many more tools were added afterwards, such as a data storage layer, an Infrastructure as Service, data analysis services and more. This took GCP to almost the same level as AWS and Azure.  

 

Here is the best part; GCP developed products that made it very attractive to the Big Data field. GCP is really geared towards developing robust big data processing tools, artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning actions and container support. Here is a review of GCP´s variety of applications.

  • Artificial intelligence & machine learning:
  • API management
  • Computation 
  • Data analytics
  • Databases
  • Developer tool
  • Internet of Things (IoT)
  • Hybrid and multi-cloud
  • Management Tools
  • Media
  • Migration
  • Networking
  • Security
  • Storage

In addition GCP offers other cloud services, among them Gsuite, Firebase, Google MKaps platform, Google cloud Identity, APigee and Orbitera.

Companies that revolve around the handling of massive amounts of data can rely on Google's BigQuery and Dataflow. The capabilities of these tools range from powerful analytics and processing to an innovative container technology (Kubernetes)  that fosters easy cluster management and deployment. And easy and effortless leveraging of AI in the cloud is taken care of by Google's Cloud Machine Learning Engine and a whole bunch of machine learning API´s.

It gets clear that GCP is already on the right path of actualising into a very effective and widely used Cloud service, especially in the Big Data world.  

Conclusion

What’s the bottom line? What can we conclude after this short perspective on the leading Cloud platforms on the planet? Well, it seems AWS, Azure and GCP are leading the various revolutions in cloud computing with each having their specific advantages over the others. 

Choosing one over the other depends on your specific business needs. But they are all leading services that excel in Accessibility; being able to access your data from whatever device you want, Convenience; everything is successfully done by the providers leaving you stressless and in complete peace of mind; Affordability; pay for what you want and only when you need the services and they all provide Ample storage space, so you can scale up whenever your needs require.

Furthermore because Azure has high level security measures in place you can have more peace of mind when using IoT solutions.<\/span><\/p>"}]},"elements":[],"widgetType":"toggle"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"7371ff70","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"705f8d00","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"36a3ddbf","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

      Now that we have set out some of the major benefits cloud services offer, we still want to showcase Google's cloud, which we will do in the next paragraphs.<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"5a456f12","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"38336713","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"440e93dc","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"What can the Google Cloud Platform (GCP) do?"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"3f243e71","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"24cfe45c","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"5b5aa64a","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

      Here\u2019s the deal Google Cloud Platform (GCP) entails a variety of\u00a0 cloud computing services. GCP arised from the Google App Engine framework meant for hosting web applications from Google's data centers. Google App Engine went public in 2008 and developed into GCP, it is considered as one of the supreme cloud computing platforms available. Even though it doesn't have the same market share as AWS or Azure it does keep in short distance from them and will probably eventually get to their level.<\/span><\/p>

      Google App Engine was a platform to build and host apps on the Google frame and eventually led to the Google Cloud Platform in 2013. Many more tools were added afterwards, such as a data storage layer, an Infrastructure as Service, data analysis services and more. This took GCP to almost the same level as AWS and Azure.\u00a0\u00a0<\/p>

      \u00a0<\/p>

      Here is the best part; GCP developed products that made it very attractive to the Big Data field. GCP is really geared towards developing robust big data processing tools, artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning actions and container support. Here is a review of GCP\u00b4s variety of applications.<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"797c224","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20"},"elements":[{"id":"4be05e5","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"6be57b3","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

      • Artificial intelligence & machine learning:<\/span><\/li>
      • API management<\/span><\/li>
      • Computation\u00a0<\/span><\/li>
      • Data analytics<\/span><\/li>
      • Databases<\/span><\/li>
      • Developer tool<\/span><\/li>
      • Internet of Things (IoT)<\/span><\/li><\/ul>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false},{"id":"bd3c831","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"1898939","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"
        • Hybrid and multi-cloud<\/span><\/li>
        • Management Tools<\/span><\/li>
        • Media<\/span><\/li>
        • Migration<\/span><\/li>
        • Networking<\/span><\/li>
        • Security<\/span><\/li>
        • Storage<\/span><\/li><\/ul>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"ce7faa7","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"4733a2f","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"86856a1","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

          In addition GCP offers other cloud services, among them Gsuite, Firebase, Google MKaps platform, Google cloud Identity, APigee and Orbitera.<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"4575fda","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"1bec256","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"aad18ad","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

          Companies that revolve around the handling of massive amounts of data can rely on Google's BigQuery and Dataflow. The capabilities of these tools range from powerful analytics and processing to an innovative container technology (Kubernetes)\u00a0 that fosters easy cluster management and deployment. And easy and effortless leveraging of AI in the cloud is taken care of by Google's Cloud Machine Learning Engine and a whole bunch of machine learning API\u00b4s.<\/span><\/p>

          It gets clear that GCP is already on the right path of actualising into a very effective and widely used Cloud service, especially in the Big Data world.\u00a0\u00a0<\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"567773ce","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"12cadf32","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"57505f1a","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Conclusion"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"1a8f6f40","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"c7dd3ee","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"4fd6e991","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

          What\u2019s the bottom line? What can we conclude after this short perspective on the leading Cloud platforms on the planet? Well, it seems AWS, Azure and GCP are leading the various revolutions in cloud computing with each having their specific advantages over the others. <\/span><\/p>\n

          Choosing one over the other depends on your specific business needs. But they are all leading services that excel in Accessibility<\/strong>; being able to access your data from whatever device you want, Convenience<\/strong>; everything is successfully done by the providers leaving you stressless and in complete peace of mind; Affordability<\/strong>; pay for what you want and only when you need the services and they all provide Ample storage space<\/strong>, so you can scale up whenever your needs require.<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false}]

item.title: The world and my experiences in it
item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded:
During the past couple of years, I’ve had to travel a little bit too much because of work. I will use this blog to post some of my experiences. If anybody would like to add something, please go ahead.My main reason for this blog is to keep a record and try to remember my experiences on each place. If you can add something, it would be nice to learn about the experiences of others and tips that may help some of us adapt better to new environments. I will start from a couple of years ago and try to remember what I can. I will use the photos I have as an aid to be as close as possible to my reality.
Also, during the process of adding my short(past) stories, I will share some of my current work activities.
Hope you enjoy this

item.title: Remembering places
item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded:
I have moved the list of places I've been to here:
http://www.xaviermorera.com/road-warrior/

item.title: Paderborn & Frankfurt (Feb 3 - 9, 2006)
item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded:
SJO airport. It’s around 6 am and I’m extremely tired as yesterday we had a party at my place. I had to say goodbye to a good friend that’s going away to study in Chile for two years. Of course I’m planning to go and visit him perhaps at mid year so we can go off roading in the snow and maybe snow boarding.
From SJO we go to MIA…3 hours later…and as usual it is as close to hell as one might think. This airport is over-used and under-attended which is the worst combination I can think of. Also please take into consideration that we are in post 9/11 times, which means that going through immigration is kind of hard, even when I have a real job and I’m attending a real training. Immigration officers can make you nervous anytime! Went through, I’m in!
After a couple of hours, we take a plane to ORD. I like this airport much better. Ate something quick, McD!, and moved on. Bought my favorite brand of sleeping pills, Unisom. I seriously object sleeping pills, unless on an overseas flight or heavily jetlagged. Any way, I still have a huge headache, so wth…I’ll take it!
9 hours later…We arrive in Frankfurt Main international airport, also known as FRA. After a quick Pass Kontrol, we enter the EU! Wohoo, we are in!
When we get there we find Paul, our coworker sleeping in a very uncomfortable chair. He took a direct flight from Miami but lost his connecting flight. We all hop in a REALLY small plane, and take the 45 minute flight to PAD airport in Padderborn.
We get there with the address of our hotel, the Vital Hotel. We only know that it is north of the city, but nothing else. A lady points out that it is a really nice hotel, actually kind of a Spa/Hotel. My first thought is: but it is snowing, who would go to a pool with snow? (however, I soon react and remember about indoor pools - hey, gimme a break! It’s been over 28 hours of traveling!).
So it’s us three, the snow and no taxis. This is a REALLY small airport. We then decide to rent a car so we go to the AVIS counter. A nice lady greets us and tells us our car is ready, but since I don’t believe in telepathy, we tell her she is confusing us. She asks us if we have a reservation and we say: “no, we just decided a minute ago to rent one”. A mix of panic and surprise shows up in her face. Of course we have a US-like way of thinking…let’s get a car and go. But here it seems that they actually get cars on a request by reservation basis. Luckily, she kind-of-likes-us so she gives us a car that somebody else was supposed to get and asks for another one. We pay and she asks who will drive. By popular decision, it will NOT be me. I kind of have a history when it comes to driving. Also, she didn’t like it very much that I asked if it was true that there are no speed limits in Germany. Well, in the AutoBahnnen there are no speed limits, everywhere else there are.
So Paul drives and we get safely to the hotel. It actually is a Spa, and a beautiful one for that. We get our rooms and go out to eat. It’s Germany, so I wanted a bratwurst. We look for a nice restaurant but it seems weekends are kind of dead here. We find a nice restaurant…opens at 5:30. It’s 5 o’clock, and we haven’t eaten decent in the last day and something so we go to the next one. Greek fast food…I’ll take it. And I got my bratwurst with fries. Very good. We asked for a plate that comes with all kinds of pork in a lot of different ways. Very good.
Next day, Paul wakes up and tells us that there are naked people going around in the snow. Yeah right! we say. It’s -1 degrees outside. We completely ignore him. I mean, who trusts an Irish mathematician that does not drink. That can’t be real. Any way, we go out to Paderborn to take a look around. It is snowing which is really nice (from inside a building anyway) and we go out to the city. We go and take a look around the city, its nice and small. We walk for a while, its a Sunday, so everything is closed. At the end we find the Cafe & Bar Celona. Very nice, had some wine and had some fun with some mind games that Paul had. Have you ever head about the Monty Hall puzzle. Well, I got it right. Then another one about some marbles, after some thinking got that one right. This went on for a while. Christian just drank wine in the meantime, I guess he didn’t enjoy this as much as I did. . We also enjoyed looking at a very pretty girl that Paul thinks was from eastern Europe
Off we go for dinner, greek again. The girl that served dinner was from Brazil, although no English. Paul lived in Paderborn and Munich for a while, so he spoke german and I took three years in the Goethe Institute in Costa Rica so I could kind of fumble my way around. More porks and fries. If you can’t speak properly the language, be careful for what you ask for. Apparently I ordered food for a small army! After ordering a normal amount of food, we went back to the hotel and decided to hit the spa. We were going to use the normal entrance to the pool area, but Paul convinced us to use another door and Voila! there was a bunch of naked people in the snow. Investigating a little further, we went inside and there was the pool, the sauna, the steam room and the changing room. Mixed! Everybody was naked. I don’t consider myself very conservative, but I draw the line there or at least I’m not that comfortable going around naked with old and young people around. I saw some things I wish I was blind.
Well, the next couple of days we had our 64-bit ISA event in the Heinz-Nixdorf Museums Forum. This is world’s largest computer museum and conference center, however almost all of it is in german. Well, the presentations went allright and the food was quite good. Of course, I miss white rice. This is funny, in Costa Rica white rice is part of most of the food you eat. You take it for granted, until you don’t have it in front of you. The museum was amazing, you could find almost any geek toy you could think of and being a geek myself, I felt like a teenager in a porno shop in A’dam.
Last day Paul took me to the airport. I was bored waiting for the plane and met the girl in the snack bar. Really pretty, totally german. A computer graphics student. She was really nice, a good conversation can pick up your spirit when you travel that much.
I got to FRA at around 6 pm. Hopped in the hotel bus and got to the Express by Holiday Inn. Nice hotel, but NO internet. This is an insult. However, this made me get up and go to downtown Frankfurt. Do not take a taxi, it will go for 20~25 euros each way. Take the train, round trip for 7 euros. Get off in Hauptwache. That’s the city center. Lot of bars and like 5 H&M! Ate also Doner. Good stuff.
Took the train back, went to the hotel and then next morning off to London Heathrow we go.

item.title: American Airlines, AA.com and “developing countries”…
item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded:
Did I fall asleep and time went by in reverse?????
That’s what I felt yesterday (for the second time actually) when I bought a ticket at AA.com and then had to go to the American Airlines main office in Costa Rica to show my credit card (YES! Literally show it to a really attitude prone girl) so that she can marka checkbox that will allow the person that I bought the ticket for to travel.
This was not like this before. I remember buying several tickets for a lot of people (actually because of work purposes) and I never had to go “show” my credit card.
I really think that if you buy something online, it should stay online. If it will continue to be this way, then I’d just rather not buy tickets online….or maybe use Expedia.
I don’t know, for you to decide….

item.title: Did my Iphone get depressed?
item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded:
First of all, I like my Iphone above all my other silicon-based toys. I think there are a lot of improvements that can be made software wise. Some of them have been covered with new updates, however mine is still in 1.1.2 because of obvious reasons (I live in Costa Rica).
However, there is one thing that really annoys me about the IPhone and that is how soft the speaker sounds. Any decent Nokia or Motorola can be used to play some music and enjoy at least with your better half. The Iphone however when I am driving my car that doesn’t have a radio, I literally have to put it inside my shirt in my shoulder to be able to hear it.
On the other hand, it vibrates really really hard. The other day I was taking a shower and the alarm went off. I couldn’t hear the phone, but surprisingly I could hear the phone vibrating on my desk. Then it happened….
CLONK!!!!!! The Iphone vibrated so hard that it started to hover and fell hard to the ground. Just feet and a half. But it landed hard.
Now I lose my signal sometimes…. Did my IPhone get depressed and tried to finish his existence…. Is he jealous that I will replace him with a 3g?
Well, let’s see how long it lasts but it looks like it’s the beggining of the end for my best electronic friend!

item.title: Customize the Windows Vista Send To Menu
item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded:
One thing I like is to keep things simple and efficient. Something else I really like is having tons of pictures on my walls. So every once in a while I send a few to print in snapfish.
The easiest way to send pictures to a folder that I will print is customizing the Send To menu in Vista. In XP and pre vista it was as easy as going into the windows folder and looking for the menu, adding a shortcut in the send to and presto, it worked.
However in Vista I couldn’t…until I found that it is the same procedure but in a different location. So, if you need to add a location in the Send To for Vista just go to %APPDATA%\Microsoft\Windows\SendTo. This folder is usually located in C:\users\<username>\AppData\Roaming.
You should now see a bunch of shortcuts. Just right click, create a new shortcut and that’s it. Just make sure that you create a shortcut to a folder that actually exists…. (I know it sounds dumb but you would be impressed at how many times I’ve seen it)

item.title: Troubleshoot SharePoint Unexpected Error
item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded: Have you ever been shocked by the fact that SharePoint is sometimes does not show a very friendly error?  Let’s say you are doing a deployment or modifying a piece of your code and in your face you get an “Unexpected error”?  Well my friend, you are not alone.   (To me, this error reminds me of the infamous catastrophic fauilure found in earlier VB which used to be my favorite runtime error) But don’t dispair, the unexpected error can be worked around given the possibility that you have access to the site’s web config. What you need to do is go into the web config and into the SharePoint > SafeMode tag just edit the CallStack attribute and set it to true.  Also you need to set the CustomErrors tag to off.  Just like magic! Your error comes up and you can understand the exception. However, be polite and return it to false when done.  And oh yes, don’t do this in production servers.  It is bad manners.  Do it in INT, Testing or PreProd environments.

item.title: Yet another blog…
item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded:
Yeah I know, I know…another geek blog. Does the world really need another one? Well, maybe it doesn’t but in any case here’s my blog.
In it I will describe my experiences working with several top of the line Microsoft technologies. Why do I get to play with everything new that pops out of MS’ oven? Well, just to give you a little bit of a background regarding me, I have worked as a Microsoft vendor (v- for those of you who are familiar with the inner workings of Corp) since 2003 in 3 different companies working with a lot of .NET, SharePoint, Office, CRM, TFS, Visual Studio and a lot of other things.
So, I plan to talk about some of the beauties and not so nice experiences I’ve had with them. Hope any of my entries help you save some time.
Well, enjoy….

item.title: Getting married
item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded:
Well, as some of my friends already know, I am getting married July 11th!!!!!
I created a little counter for my girlfriend so that she can open and find out how long before we get married hehehehe. It's in http://www.moreragutierrez.com
Nothing fancy, just something a geek would do for a girl. I really love her (yes yes "aww so cute"). But it is true. Sometimes you would do anything for someone you love.
Big step. Completely decided on doing it. I really hope it works. She is quite a chick, let's see if I can live up to her expectations.

item.title: Is quitting a company just like ending a relationship?
item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded:
I recently quit my job, actually two weeks ago. Basically differences with my partner.
My question is the following, after I quit the company should I stop all communication with the people I used to work with? It's kind of hard given that I pretty much interviewed and hired each one of them. Also, they are a great group and have a lot of skills and potential.
But, it all comes to the say question...is good bye final? At least for now?

item.title: Taking a train in Costa Rica
item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded:
I took the train today thanks to the vehicular restriction I have on Thursdays. To my surprise, it works pretty good! Less than $1 and extremely fast compared to other methods of transportation.
Of course there is always something bad, you can get robbed, shot, or in the best case wet!

item.title: Our super accessible train
item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded:
I think the train is wonderful, but for accessibility it gets a -10000
I didn't notice, but the platform is almost 3 feet above the ground. I don't think that is nice for older people or with limitations!
Update: today I looked to the left. There is a ramp!!!!!!!!!

item.title: Installing SQL Server 2008 Express on Windows Server 2003
item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded: I decided today to give it a shot installing SQL Server 2008 Express. http://www.microsoft.com/express/sql/default.aspx One note, I am doing so in Windows Server 2003 R2.  Why? It is a VM and I had the license for an Enterprise so I decided to use it. For starters, I needed to install .Net Framework 3.5 SP1 http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?familyid=ab99342f-5d1a-413d-8319-81da479ab0d7&displaylang=en Guess what.... reboot! (I really hope that the day comes when it is not required to reboot every single time I change something in Windows.... Another step more "Setup requires Windows Installer 4.5 or higher".... So http://www.microsoft.com/downloadS/details.aspx?familyid=5A58B56F-60B6-4412-95B9-54D056D6F9F4&displaylang=en Installed.  Reboot...again.... Now what else?  Lot of tests passed, however Windows Power Shell missing http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=10EE29AF-7C3A-4057-8367-C9C1DAB6E2BF&displaylang=en Installed, re-run tests.  Pass. Select what to install.  Personally selected Database Engine and Management Tools.  Next, next, next.... Added myself as admin and use my user.  I just need to install a test db.  However, long process! Finally, installing! Wait quite a bit, and you are ready to roll.  Looks pretty nice, however installing should be a bit easier.  Especially since it is Express.

item.title: ASP.NET v2.0.50727 missing in Web Services Extensions in IIS Manager
item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded:
If you are installing SharePoint and you bump into the issue that ASP Net v2.0 is not in the Web Server Extensions, then you could do a research and find out that you installed a newer version of the framework, namely SP1.
According to Microsoft, you need to uninstall SP1, install .Net 2.0 and then move from there: http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx/KB/906894
Sounds a bit dumb
But don't worry, go to C:\WINDOWS\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v2.0.50727> or C:\WINDOWS\Microsoft.NET\Framework64\v2.0.50727> for 64 bit
Type aspnet_regiis.exe –i
A lot easier!

item.title: Hoy puse esta queja a AMNET - PESIMO servicio al cliente
item.dc:creator: Xavier
item.content:encoded: El sabado vinieron a hacer una reparacion de internet (que yo SI tenia internet), pues apenas se fue el muchacho se cayo internet. Llame a solicitar que lo arreglaron y me dijeron que ya era muy tarde que llamara el domingo. Llamo el domingo y despues de 40 minutos en espera me dicen que "lo siento, es un domingo y no podemos ayudarlo". Hoy fui a amnet y me dijeron que hoy venian (me atendio oscar aparicio de la sabana) y tampoco estan aca. ASi que fui y compre un datacard kolbi y estoy conectado y funciona perfecto asi que #1 por favor vengan martes 5 de octubre y me reparan mi conexion URGENTEMENTE (ya perdi 3 dias de trabajo, paciencia, mill llamadas - sabian que la espera promedio para un tecnico de amnet es de media hora en el telefono, lo cual es ridiculo) #2 si no pueden venir mannana, por favor entonces tramitar la desconexion de mi servicio y me quedo con Kolbi

item.title: Apache Hive
item.dc:creator: viva
item.content:encoded:
What is Apache Hive and Why Should I Use It?

The chief theme of this post is to understand what Hive is and why you should use it. In other words, what is Hive´s unique architecture and capabilities, what are it´s disadvantages and where is it used today?

Why was Apache Hive developed?

In 2007 facebook was confronted with a fastly growing number of data. It grew from a 15TB data set  to a 2PB data set today. They were lacking the means to process this data adequately, they needed an infrastructure that could scale along with their data. Luckily for them they were able to use Hadoop to solve this issue. Using Hadoop made things easier and less time consuming. However, the Hadoop ecosystem is not easy to get used to. And most of the organizations with traditional data warehouses use SQL, relying on SQL queries for extracting data. So, they brought the familiar concepts of tables, columns, partitions and a subset of SQL to the unstructured world of Hadoop, without sacrificing the extensibility and flexibility that Hadoop brings. In 2008 Hive became open source and remains popular to Hadoop users for their data processing needs. It is used a lot for simple summarization jobs, business intelligence, machine learning and many other applications.

What is Apache Hive?

Apache Hive is an open source project run at the Apache Software Foundation. It has become a top – level project. Apache hive is used and developed by big companies such as Amazon, Netflix and the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA). This open source data warehouse software is used for reading, writing and managing large data set files that are stored directly in either the Apache Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS) or other data storage systems such as Apache HBase. With Hive, SQL developers can write Hive Query language to access and analyze data in Hadoop using the SQL syntax. So, Hive is basically a tool in the Hadoop ecosystem which provides an interface to organize and query data in a database.

How does Apache Hive work?

Hive organizes data in tables and partitions. It does this by bringing SQL intellect to the Hadoop ecosystem. Users can write SQL like queries called HQL or hive query language to extract data from Hadoop. The hive component converts these SQL like queries into map reduce jobs to be able to talk to the Hadoop ecosystem and HDFS file system. Thanks to this data warehouse infrastructure tool, processing structured data in Hadoop becomes possible. Hive resides on top of Hadoop to summarize Big Data, and makes querying and analyzing easy.

What are the main advantages of Apache Hive?

It stores schema in a database and processes data into HDFS Great, but what is HDFS? HDFS is a distributed file system. It can handle large data sets that run on commodity hardware. HDFS can scale a single Apache Hadoop cluster to hundreds (and even thousands) of nodes. It is one of the major components of Apache Hadoop, the others being MapReduce and YARN. Hive is created for OLAP Wait, but what is OLAP you ask? OLAP stands for Online Analytical Processing. It is a technology used for many Business Intelligence (BI) applications, such as data discovery, complex analytical calculations and making predictions. It provides SQL type language for querying called HiveQL or HQL. Ow, what is HQL again? HQL allows us to project structure on largely unstructured data.  So what is the difference between SQL and HiveQL? Well, Hive executes queries on Hadoop’s infrastructure instead of on a traditional database. Hive is scalable, fast, and uses familiar concepts In other words Hive uses similar concepts found in relational databases, such as columns, tables, rows, and schema, etc. Hive has the potential to grow in time, it can efficiently handle more and more requests. Hive offers fast and simple data retrieval How exactly does Hive do this?  Hive is fast because it uses Partitioning. Partitioning avoids scanning of the entire table. Hive uses where clauses to select partitions. If we specify the partitioned columns in the where clause it will not scan the entire table and is able to retrieve data fast. But how do we avoid over partitioning in Hive? To overcome over partitioning we can use Bucketing or a combination of Partitioning and Bucketing:  Bucketing is similar to partitioning but unlike partitioning it can divide large datasets into more manageable parts known as buckets. Therefore, when the implementation of partitioning becomes difficult, we can use bucketing in Hive.

When not to use Apache Hive?

  • OLTP (Online Line Transaction Processing)
  • Ad hoc real time queries
  • No ACID support (ACID support is limited)
  • Not suited for frequent updates and inserts
  • small data sets
  • Not meant for unstructured data analysis

Conclusion

Well, now we have given you a brief overview of what Hive exactly is. We know you might want to get a better understanding of Hadoop and many other technologies used by the Big Data community. That is exactly what we will be doing in our following posts! Stay tuned and get all the latest insights into the magical and revolutionizing world of Big Data!

[{"id":"5e86c21","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"4e55cfa","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"71c85cc","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.xaviermorera.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/WhatsApp-Image-2020-09-22-at-17.22.16.jpeg","id":1753},"image_size":"medium","image_box_shadow_box_shadow_type":"yes"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"83e1b1f","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"f4cc19d","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"6d518c3","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"What is Apache Hive and Why Should I Use It?"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"13a9171","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"ee59012","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"e9df5e2","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

The chief theme of this post is to understand what Hive is and why you should use it. In other words, what is Hive\u00b4s unique architecture and capabilities, what are it\u00b4s disadvantages and where is it used today?<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"466ed88","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"9fdf206","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"ef5b426","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Why was Apache Hive developed?"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"4bb6c87","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"d3ca9ae","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"6c8eb9e","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

In 2007 facebook was confronted with a fastly growing number of data. It grew from a 15TB data set\u00a0 to a 2PB data set today. They were lacking the means to process this data adequately, they needed an infrastructure that could scale along with their data. Luckily for them they were able to use Hadoop to solve this issue. Using Hadoop made things easier and less time consuming.<\/span><\/p>

However, the Hadoop ecosystem is not easy to get used to. And most of the organizations with traditional data warehouses use SQL, relying on SQL queries for extracting data. So, they brought the familiar concepts of tables, columns, partitions and a subset of SQL to the unstructured world of Hadoop, without sacrificing the extensibility and flexibility that Hadoop brings. In 2008 Hive became open source and remains popular to Hadoop users for their data processing needs. It is used a lot for simple summarization jobs, business intelligence, machine learning and many other applications.<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"5d2021c","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"ff67459","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"ff7e14b","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"What is Apache Hive?"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"14c3f22","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"0bd6bdc","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"0fb6022","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Apache Hive is an open source project run at the Apache Software Foundation. It has become a top \u2013 level project. Apache hive is used and developed by big companies such as Amazon, Netflix and the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA). This open source data warehouse software is used for reading, writing and managing large data set files that are stored directly in either the Apache Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS) or other data storage systems such as Apache HBase. With Hive, SQL developers can write Hive Query language to access and analyze data in Hadoop using the SQL syntax. So, Hive is basically a tool in the Hadoop ecosystem which provides an interface to organize and query data in a database.<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"ca9c3fa","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"e1416b0","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"9d84d56","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.xaviermorera.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/WhatsApp-Image-2020-09-22-at-17.21.52.jpeg","id":1752},"image_size":"medium","image_box_shadow_box_shadow_type":"yes"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"90158e5","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"f444b8c","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"5a8614f","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"How does Apache Hive work?"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"89aee5d","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"fba0e30","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"5184508","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Hive organizes data in tables and partitions. It does this by bringing SQL intellect to the Hadoop ecosystem. Users can write SQL like queries called HQL or hive query language to extract data from Hadoop. The hive component converts these SQL like queries into map reduce jobs to be able to talk to the Hadoop ecosystem and HDFS file system. Thanks to this data warehouse infrastructure tool, processing structured data in Hadoop becomes possible. Hive resides on top of Hadoop to summarize Big Data, and makes querying and analyzing easy.<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"accf79b","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"aaeb13f","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"a656bca","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"What are the main advantages of Apache Hive?"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"e4d5df8","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"aa8c825","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"e52110f","elType":"widget","settings":{"tabs":[{"tab_title":"It stores schema in a database and processes data into HDFS","tab_content":"

Great, but what is HDFS? HDFS is a distributed file system. It can handle large data sets that run on commodity hardware. HDFS can scale a single Apache Hadoop cluster to hundreds (and even thousands) of nodes. It is one of the major components of Apache Hadoop, the others being MapReduce and YARN.<\/span><\/p>","_id":"8693dfc"},{"tab_title":"Hive is created for OLAP","tab_content":"

Wait, but what is OLAP you ask? OLAP stands for Online Analytical Processing. It is a technology used for many Business Intelligence (BI) applications, such as data discovery, complex analytical calculations and making predictions.<\/span><\/p>","_id":"b340d3a"},{"_id":"334914a","tab_title":"It provides SQL type language for querying called HiveQL or HQL.","tab_content":"

Ow, what is HQL again? HQL allows us to project structure on largely unstructured data.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>

So what is the difference between SQL and HiveQL?<\/span><\/p>

Well, Hive executes queries on Hadoop's infrastructure instead of on a traditional database.<\/span><\/p>"},{"_id":"1978cd3","tab_title":"Hive is scalable, fast, and uses familiar concepts","tab_content":"

In other words Hive uses similar concepts found in relational databases, such as columns, tables, rows, and schema, etc. Hive has the potential to grow in time, it can efficiently handle more and more requests.<\/span><\/p>"},{"_id":"86f978f","tab_title":"Hive offers fast and simple data retrieval","tab_content":"

How exactly does Hive do this?\u00a0<\/span><\/p>

\u00a0<\/p>

Hive is fast because it uses Partitioning. Partitioning avoids scanning of the entire table. Hive uses where clauses to select partitions. If we specify the partitioned columns in the where clause it will not scan the entire table and is able to retrieve data fast.<\/span><\/p>

\u00a0<\/p>

But how do we avoid over partitioning in Hive? To overcome over partitioning we can use Bucketing or a combination of Partitioning and Bucketing:\u00a0<\/span><\/p>

\u00a0<\/p>

Bucketing is similar to partitioning but unlike partitioning it can divide large datasets into more manageable parts known as buckets. Therefore, when the implementation of partitioning becomes difficult, we can use bucketing in Hive.<\/span><\/p>"}]},"elements":[],"widgetType":"toggle"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"9ad4591","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"db8fd2a","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"b0c6669","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"When not to use Apache Hive?"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"86af6fb","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20"},"elements":[{"id":"83bef44","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"54b86d4","elType":"widget","settings":{"icon_list":[{"text":"OLTP (Online Line Transaction Processing)","selected_icon":{"value":"fas fa-times","library":"fa-solid"},"_id":"583b7cf"},{"text":"Ad hoc real time queries","selected_icon":{"value":"fas fa-times","library":"fa-solid"},"_id":"ba78a36"},{"text":"No ACID support (ACID support is limited)","selected_icon":{"value":"fas fa-times","library":"fa-solid"},"_id":"22e1078"}]},"elements":[],"widgetType":"icon-list"}],"isInner":false},{"id":"77036ce","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"a46310a","elType":"widget","settings":{"icon_list":[{"text":"Not suited for frequent updates and inserts","selected_icon":{"value":"fas fa-times","library":"fa-solid"},"_id":"312d37b"},{"text":" small data sets","selected_icon":{"value":"fas fa-times","library":"fa-solid"},"_id":"c4fe96a"},{"text":"Not meant for unstructured data analysis","selected_icon":{"value":"fas fa-times","library":"fa-solid"},"_id":"00b253e"}]},"elements":[],"widgetType":"icon-list"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"f691b9e","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"f955c4c","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"4b43d68","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Conclusion"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"57b973c","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"98bb1b0","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"0b4f7d8","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Well, now we have given you a brief overview of what Hive exactly is. We know you might want to get a better understanding of Hadoop and many other technologies used by the Big Data community. That is exactly what we will be doing in our following posts! Stay tuned and get all the latest insights into the magical and revolutionizing world of Big Data!<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false}]

item.title: Apache Spark
item.dc:creator: viva
item.content:encoded:
What is Apache Spark?

Spark can be considered as an ultra fast distributed data processing engine. It is called “a lightning fast unified analytics engine for big data and machine learning”. Spark will help you to handle big data sets extremely fast. It does this by breaking up the task into pieces and delegating them across computational resources. It is also capable of distributing data processing tasks across multiple computers. Alone or with the help of other distributed computing tools. It is generally considered as the largest open source project in data processing. This unified analytics engine is massively used by a comprehensive range of industries, used by Netflix, Yahoo and Ebay among many many other big companies. A massive amount of people contribute to its development, making it the largest open source project ever. 

The origin of Apache Spark

Apache Spark originated in 2009 at the UC Berkeley AMPLab and became open source in 2010, In 2013 Spark became part of the Apache Software Foundation where thousands of people still contribute to its success.

Apache Spark´s difference with Hadoop

To really understand how Spark differs from Hadoop consider that Hadoop uses multiple workers to handle various separate tasks when all the work is thoroughly finished everything is brought together. This considerably lengthens the time of completion. With Spark not all the work needs to be done at the same time, also Spark is compatible with various programming languages whereas Hadoop needs Apache Hive to enable communication. To answer the question as to why Apache Spark is so important, consider that we definitely need an engine that can react in the blink of an eye and work in - memory. Apache Spark surely clears the way for lightning speed data processing and easy development. Its whole ecosystem makes Apache Spark speedy and reliable.

What are other benefits of Apache Spark?

Velocity As mentioned before Spark is considerably faster than Hadoop when processing massive data sets. It is also fast when the data is put on disk and even has a world record for large scale on disc sorting. As mentioned before Spark is lightning fast because it works via controlled partitioning. Working with the data through partitions, enabling parallelized distributed data processing leading to a minimal network traffic. Convenient Spark comes with many user friendly API’s when working on massive data sets. It also has a large collection of operators for the transformation and manipulation of data. An interconnected Engine Spark is supported by higher grade libraries such as help with SQL queries, machine learning, graph processing, streaming data and more. You can combine them easily to enable intricate processes.  It gets even better, in the following we will go over more features that Apache Spark provides.

FEATURES

Multi lingual Spark is a true speaker of many languages, Java, Scala, Python, R, Spark works with all of them! Various Data Formats Spark is compatible with various data formats;  Parquet, JSON, Hive and Cassandra are all possible. There is a pluggable mechanism where we can access structured data though Spark SQL. Laid back Evaluation It will delay evaluation until it really needs to. This is exactly what makes it so fast. Only when the driver really requests data will it start executing. Real Time Computation  Spark computes in real-time and with less latency because it does in-memory computation. Spark is meant for massive scalability and it can therefore run production clusters with thousands of nodes and can support several computational models. Works great together with Hadoop Apache Spark is perfectly compatible with Hadoop. It could replace the MapReduce functions of Hadoop and can run on top of an existing Hadoop cluster using YARN for resource scheduling. Machine Learning The machine learning part of Spark is called MLlib. MLib greatly reduces the need for multiple tools. Helping us to process data efficiently and – we can’t stress it enough-  in an extremely fast way.

What are the elements in Spark´s ecosystem?

Spark Core Spark core as its name suggests has all the essential elements for task scheduling, memory management, fault recovery and more. Spark SQL Spark SQL is used when we are working with structured data. It works with SQL as well as Apache Hive´s Hive Query Language (HQL). It can also easily deal with many sources of data like parse tables, log files, JSON, etc. With Spark SQL we can combine SQL queries with the programmatic data manipulations handled by RDD in Python, Java, Scala, and R. Spark Streaming This is perfect when processing live streams of data. Consider instances such as log files generated by web servers and systems, messages with status updates and more. GraphX We can use GraphX for handling graphs and graph-parallel computation. It makes solving graph analytics problems much much easier. MLlib Spark comes with a library containing common Machine Learning (ML) functionality called MLlib. Thanks to MLib we can do the usual ML algorithms including regression, clustering, and classification.

Conclusion

With the introduction of Apache Spark we witnessed a true revolution in the world of Big Data, seriously transcending Hadoop´s capabilities. With some impressive features such as in-memory processing, massive parallel processing, machine learning applications and many more of the most essential applications! It makes it easy to understand why Apache Spark is used by so many companies in various industries. Apache Sparks' success story does not end here, on the contrary a bright future lies ahead for this powerful lightning fast data processing engine.

item.title: Tez
item.dc:creator: viva
item.content:encoded:
What is Tez in data processing?

Tez greatly enhances the possibilities of Hadoop, it goes beyond MapReduce, thereby considerably offering more flexibility and performance. Tez only focuses on data movement and not on data format, it offers a more potent structure that is grounded on expressing computations as a dataflow graph. Because Hadoop works with MapReduce to batch-process large amounts of data, it doesn't perform well with near-real-time performance of query processing. Various tasks like for instance Machine Learning cannot be executed well with the MapReduce paradigm. That is why Tez was developed to solve these issues in Hadoop Tez is built on Yarn, which stands for Yet Another Resource Negotiator, it provides cluster resource management to Hadoop so that multiple data processing engines can handle data stored in a single platform. With Tez the same processing is possible in only one job and there is no need to access HDFS in between.

The origin of Tez

In 2013 Hortonworks and the Apache community set up the Singer Initiative, it was a 3 phase project aimed at solving the SQL issues with Hadoop. In the past, when running a SQL query on Hadoop the data stores consumed all the cluster resources leading to performance issues for other applications and jobs that were active in the cluster. Fixing these SQL issues was a top priority in those days. And furthermore MapReduce is not known by many and is definitely not easy to use.  The singer Initiative focused on Hive, the SQL engine for Hadoop, but they also wanted to enhance performance with YARN. Wanting to get out of the MapReduce paradigm, they developed a structure that reduced latency for complex data tasks, this became known as Tez. MapReduce is slow, definitely not user friendly, and overly rigid. MapReduce and Tez do use the same logical programming paradigm, but Tez uses dataflow DAGs for its resource optimization and data pipeline planning. So, Tez is considerably faster than MapReduce but it still also has the same rigid design limitations.

How does Tez work? What is its Data Processing Paradigm?

As mentioned Tez is still very similar to MapReduce with the technological advancement of using a DAG or Directed Acyclical graph when defining workflows. Thereby offering massive flexibility in the execution environment, this also simplifies development and consequently increasing speed. When workflows are defined as a DAG the optimizer is able to look at the workflow in its entirety when it is planning execution. In this way it can schedule when data can be held in memory and when it needs to hit disk. This is another advantage Tez has compared to MapReduce, namely data pipelining. With Tez there are no more MapReduce pre-clogged pipes. Tez does work with the Mapper and Reducer but when we don´t need to write each intermediate step to disk, then it will omit this step. In short, Tez processes the same workflow written in MapReduce considerably faster.

What is Tez´ Interface or how do you use it?

Again we said it before, because jobs done with Tez are logically very similar to MapReduce jobs, the API calls are also very similar. The Stinger Initiative envisioned a MapReduce replacement that was highly compatible with Hive that uses MapReduce to do the work. Consequently Hive, Pig, Cascading and other interfaces that generate MapReduce can also now generate Tez code.

In review: what were the 2 main design themes for Tez?

Let us take a close look at the main design goals behind Tez. With what aims in mind did they create Tez and therefore how does Tez prove to be a considerable progress from the Hadoop functionality? User friendliness:
    • APIs that have an expressive dataflow expression
    • Works with a flexible Input-Processor-Output runtime model
    • Tez is data type agnostic
    • It has a deployment that is simplified
Execution Performance
  • Performs much better than Map Reduce
      • Manages resource in the best possible way
      • Schedules reconfiguration at runtime
      • Makes dynamic physical data flow decisions
Tez enables projects like Apache Hive and Apache Pig to run a complex DAG of tasks, so that data that earlier took multiple MapReduce jobs, can now be done in a single job by using Tez.

Spark vs. Tez: What's the Difference?

Any perspective on Tez needs to include a comparison between Tez and Apache Spark. Apache Spark and Hadoop MapReduce are widely used in the Big data world. Apache Spark is a data processing structure that offers high performance and in memory data processing. Whereas Hadoop MapReduce is a batch processing structure for the petabyte scale.  With Tez we have something similar to Spark but in the Hadoop framework. Apache Spark and Tez both use directed acyclic graphs, so how do they differ? The main differences have to do with Hive and Pig, Hadoop YARN and performance tests. Below we clearly point out the 4 main differences between Apache Spark and Tez:
  1. Tez matches perfectly on the YARN architecture. Spark may run into resource management issues.
  2. Spark is more for mainstream developers, while Tez is a framework for purpose-built tools.
  3. Spark can't run concurrently with YARN applications at this point in time. Tez is purposefully built to execute on top of YARN.
  4. Tez's containers can shut down when finished to save resources. Spark's containers will take up resources even when they are not processing data.

Conclusion

Tez is a distributed execution framework that works with DAG or computations represented as dataflow graphs. It works perfectly with languages like Hive, Pig, Cascading, etc. It's created to have a highly customizable execution architecture to enable us to execute dynamic performance optimizations at runtime based on real time information about the data and the resources. Tez works equally well with slow batch, large scale jobs that MapReduce is good for, such as ETL (Extract Transform Load) style jobs. With the main difference that Tez will massively save you time when doing slow batch jobs. Going from 20 hours to 2 hours is something each of us would prefer. Tez definitely erases the need to use MapReduce by saving you time, stress and effort.
